author: Anubis_

description.text:
The Micro extruder was not small enough (still over 70mm) for me so i designed a new body from scratch. With the smaller size a new uniX-hotend V2 assembly version is released ! Features:

  • very compact design, only 50mm tall !!!

  • Overall weight of complete extruder with hotend can be under 200 gramms !

  • uni-X V2 Universal Hotend system -> Works with alot of different Hotends
    (no need of a metalplate for V9/v10 Hotend anymore !!!)

  • 50mm assembly holes

  • should work with 3mm and 1,75 material (using brass tub insert)
    • Still missing: fanmount -> can be used from a other PG35 extruder.
  • i already made some specific hotend derivates from this with only 43mm height, maybe i`ll release them later (some weeks)

EDIT: fixed version uploaded -> added support to upper Filamentguide. EDIT2: uploaded some bearingholderfor the extrudershaft. Testprint was made with 0,35mm layerwith and 0,28 layer height. Zip contains again a set of 16,4mm insets and one with 16,7mm (for well tuned printer ;) ). Vitamins:
1x PG35L Stepperdriver
1x MK7 Pulley or similar
6x M3 nut
4x M3 washer (some additional springwasher for extruder recommended)
4x M3x40 screw
1x 624Z bearing
1x 3x14mm bolt (for idler bearing)
2x small springs for Idler
2x M4 Nylock nuts + screws for mounting the extruder on the carriage

comments.text: I've been having problems with my PG35l motor. I have to set my extruder acceleration down to 500 mm/s^2 in the firmware in order to get retraction to work, but then my print quality suffers. I have great quality at 1200 mm/s^2 but no retraction.  My actual retraction speed is set at 20-30 mm/s.  My ability to retract seems to depend on how high I set my extruder acceleration in the firmware but is also affecting quality.  Have you ever had similar issues?  Thanks for the help

comments.text: I'm afraid I'm in the same boat as rrhb - I don't know what the insets are. Does this somehow get filled in by the inset??  Are the insets meant to be printed separately and then inserted into the body, or are the somehow merged as meshes and sliced together? description.text:
I have a plastic 5 gallon gas can. It's from a company called "Midwest Can" - they are pretty common. The first thing that breaks is the cap. It tends to split, so you can replace it with a printed one. It should be noted that ABS and PLA don't hold up to gasoline - I think nylon would be OK. I'm storing used engine oil in my container so I printed my cap in ABS.

This is a parametric design so you can adjust the size of it to fit your own application.

Features:

Knurled cap for a good grip.
Buttress threads.

Note: This is not OpenSCAD. It's a program written in Go. The main library and code examples can be found here:

https://github.com/deadsy/sdfx

About Go: https://golang.org/

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40703 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=40703

Using the following options: pattern_thickness = 5
build_plate_selector = 0
pattern_radius = 8
pattern_overlap = 42
iphone_version = 2
case_thickness = 1.8
pattern_rotation = 0
pattern_shape = 6

I had a desire to make some small chain drives for some of my models, but wanted to use some classic chain link style chair rather than proper chain drive chain. I had a look on thingiverse and discovered that nobody else had made a model for this. So, after scratching around with a pencil to work out what parameters I needed, I jumped on OpenSCAD and came up with two parametric models. This one is just a disk with the chain recesses which can be easily adapted to other pulley body designs using your vertex modeller of choice. The other is designed to crew onto a shaft and so it fitted with a neck, holes and nut slots.

The chain size and number of link pairs determines the size of the pulley. So the important variables to fiddle with are;

Llength: This is the outside length dimension of a single link
Lwidth: This is the outside width dimension of a single link
Lthickness: This is the diameter of the link “wire”

N: The number of chain link pairs around the pulley. Please note this is pairs of links not the number of single links.

Pwidth: Width of the pulley main drum which the chain recesses are cut into.

There are a bunch of other parameters that you may wish to tweak too;

Ptol: Is the printing tolerance. It is used to provide a bit of space around the chain profile so that chain will fit into the recess despite a bit of spread from the extruded plastic.
PtolThk: This is a printing allowance for the "radially" orientated link thickness. This allows a bit of extra on either side of the link slot so any sagging of the printed filament can be easily removed or at least won't interfere with the link sliding into the slot.
Wclr: On either side the the tangential link is a cutout slot. This parameter just controls the size of this slot.

Hopefully this is all clear enough.

I feel the model will work well for larger chains where the printing tolerances are less of a factor in the final printed shape.

I trust this will be useful to you.

title: Bolt-on Flashforge Creator Pro/Powerspec Ultra Filament Guide

description.text:
There are already a few designs of the filament guide for these 3D printers available. Most if not all are two sided (for left and right extruders) and installed with the existing straps. In my case, one of the straps is broken and I can't use it. Therefore, I designed this simple single-sided bracket which is bolted on. It is very sturdy even at 5% infill.

To install, you unscrew the original plastic parts and replace with this part (use the same screws). You then slide the filament tube through the eyelets which hold it in place by friction. I use 1/4" OD polyethylene tube, but I think 6 mm OD tube should work fine.

Note that you must print this in vertical orientation. Otherwise it will break easily because of the low z-strength.

author: apsbiker

title: SimplifyVR SVR-206 GoPro Hero4 Panoramic Video VR Panorama 360 Rig

description.text:
We are slowly releasing all of the designs for our 360 rigs here on Thingiverse -- we have sold many but the market is slowing down for 360 rigs while our threaded inserts used in them are getting more and more popular. We hope releasing the STL files freely will encourage greater adoption of our designs, and we intend to continue supplying the inserts for the long term, and the COTS components for at least the medium term.

This is a 6-camera 360 rig designed for the GoPro Hero4. It worked well for us while we were based in Alaska. Now that we are based in Georgia (the state), we don't come across many scenes worthy of 360 photography :-(

You will also need a variety of threaded inserts -- which is now our primary product line.
These are available on both eBay and Amazon.
The corners use 1/4-20 (long) inserts,while the camera prong connectors use #6-32 (short) inserts. The latch requires an M5 (short) insert, and a standard GoPro style thumbscrew.
Our eBay listings are here:
http://stores.ebay.com/Albers-LLC?_dmd=2&_nkw=inserts
while our Amazon listings can be found by searching for "initeq inserts"

author: mussy

description.text:
2.4GhZ AMP enclosure for RC Radio powered by it's own 3S batt. To increase power output of my FrSky Taranis Plus from pathetic 85mw stock, to whooping 2.5W.

Enclosure provides independent power source (3S LiPo), In order not to drain in Radio's battery. Also, voltage alarm, power switch and voltage booster, since the power needed to run the amplifier is 12V constant and lipos are dropping in voltage during normal discharge down to 10.4v and lower, which would impact Amp's peak performance.

Parts needed to complete the project:

1- Rocking switch, found in computer power supply boxes.
1-XT-60 Female Connector
1-LiPo Voltage Alarm
1-3S Lipo Battery with XT-60 Plug
1-2.5W WiFi Amplifier

Sunhans Sh-2500 2500mw Wireless Signal Repeater 33dbm Wifi Signal Booster 2.5w
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HJ1NQLS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

  1. DIGITEN DC 6V 5-11V to 12V 2A Step up Converter

I needed holder for my cellphone in my car. I do not use old lighter port, so I utilized it to hold my cellphone.

These are simple gantry rest brackets to be used to evenly support gantry on both side to adjust the gantry carriages or do other related forms of maintenance. I printed the smaller versions, but when adding ThingiRob's EZgimbals to my dual Z system, it was somewhat tough being so low, so I added another 50-60mm to the height. These would be great for leveling the gantry as they transfer the level of the base frame upwards. Bed leveling will be easier as a result.

Print both A and B to make a pair.

Edit - I modded Tall Gantry Rests to remove material from the middle of the triangular rib which will increase strength while limiting materials used.
Just a drop :)

title: RealAcc x210 VTX Antenna mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I borrowed from the design of the VTX Antenna holder that came shipped with my SuperLight 5 inch Norris Edition frame. Needed one to fit on my RealAcc x210 so that my VTX antenna doesn't get damaged by prop strikes. I just made my rendition slightly different, i.e. it's not as thick on the part that goes on the stand-offs, and it doesn't take a phenomenal effort to slide them on or off which winds up scratching up your stand-offs because with the version that came shipped, the only way was to use needle-nose pliers. With my version, it only requires just enough exertion with your thumb and index fingers. Also, the part that encloses the standoffs aren't as tall as the Catalyst version. So, that your antenna sits higher in case you are using a VTX like the Tramp which has a pig-tail adaptor

Print this using TPU and be sure to include supports.

comments.text: I printed mine without supports without issue. The drill holes are so small there should be no issue in creating the overhang required to preserve them. This is a remix combining two filament sensor housings. I bought endstop sensors by mistake (commonly used for 3d printers)(https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01N1WQA48/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and did not find one that used this type of sensor plus attached to the extruder.

https://www.thingiverse.com/STIG_

V2, updated one of the holes to allow easier install of the filament to the extruder.

V3 - I widened the hole for the filament so PTFE tube can be put before and after the sensor. I noticed that it was rubbing on the plastic in areas which could cause snags. using the PTFE tubing ensures that the filament moves smoothly.

This is a tool/jig to set the correct distance between stone and toolholder/bar on a number of popular wetgrinders like tormek, sheppach and others.

It also contains a gauge to set suitable protrusion if using the gouge jig from tormek.

I chose to print this in the elaborate and somewhat flamboyant "Copper Rust" pla. You can choose any other inferior colour you might like. ;)

UPDATE 19/01/2018: Edited the model to make sure the holes slip onto the guide rod better.

The resolution will matter if you want to use this interchangeably with another similar tool. In this case, it must be accurate in order for you to produce a consistent grind on your tools. If you only use this one, it makes no real difference if it's ever so slightly inaccurate - the point is consistency.
scale it for your desired size.

title: Creality CR-10 Z axis cable drag chain

description.text:
Drag chain assembly for CR-10 to manage cabling from the X carriage (hotend, X motor and end-stop, extruder motor) so that it doesn't just hang freely. Works only with cable extensions, especially the hot-end cable assembly with the aviation plug.

Requires:

  • 3x t-bolt hammer slot nuts + bolts
  • 1x M5 50 mm bolt (can reuse the nut from the current wheel bolt assembly)
  • zip ties to hold cable to top and bottom brackets.

Chain links are wider than those used for my Y axis cable chain (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2708420)

Print:
10x bottom links (100% infill)

Unlikely this will fix your welder but posted in case it helps someone. This is for a cheap MIG130 gasless welder, I modded the thing for DC welding too with a rectifier (second photo, DCEN .. gun negative for FCAW, MASSIVE improvement to spatter etc).
The problem was the wire feeding on after trigger released meaning the wire would often stick to the weld pool, adding this brake has helped a great deal to minimise the run on, all it had before was more of a retainer with minimal tension and no adjustment. Tap the 2 holes and add 15mmx3mm bolts to adjust tension.

title: Sony BP MZ-1 battery pack replacement based on 18650-type batteries

description.text:
Tried to revive my 1992 Sony MZ-1 MiniDisc recorder 'off grid' by means of two 18650 batteries and the 3D print on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2297082
However, that model has several issues w.r.t. sizing and alignment of the batteries with the device's contacts.

So I designed a 2-part battery holder from scratch using SketchUp (file included, feel free to adapt). After printing the model, I added aluminium contacts made of thicker aluminium sheet, which is very easy to find in any convenience store under the form of aluminium cups or recipients typically used for barbecue and oven. You could try regular aluminium wrap as well, but imho that's too frilly, and I don't want to risk causing any shorts.

Look at the images on how to position both parts. Normally, I first gently slide in the part with the 2 separate contacts, then the batteries (the right one first, WATCH POLARITY!!!), and finally the part with the single contact. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RLMs_pZKgLs&feature=youtu.be if you still feel unsure on how to do it.

Works really flawless, every time. And as an added bonus: the MZ-1 plays many many hours with just two 18650 batteries.

If you have no printer, but would like to have this print, feel free to contact me through Facebook.

author: navarrma

description.text:
The device allows simple access to the working area of the extruder allowing its easy maintenance.
It replaces the original radiator that, according to result of a study on 3dtoday.ru (http://3dtoday.ru/blogs/sim31/facilitated-the-extruder-anet-a6-19-grams-by-removing-unnecessary-deta/) is ineffective, very slightly contributing to cooling of the extruder’s thermo-barrier, but almost completely shutting off airflow into the feeder area, which requires cooling the most.
In operation state the closed wicket leaves free access to the airflow from the fan, creating more comfortable surroundings to the feeding filament. The air is exhausted from the extruder upwards, protecting materials sensitive to cold draft as ABS.
When some maintenance inside the feeder is required, the wicket is opened by one move instead of full disassembly of the node (very uncomfortable due it being mounted under spring suspension).
The closed wicket is fixed by a magnet; its opening is limited up to 120 degrees.
The device assembly includes the following additional parts:

  • Round magnet 4x1mm – 1 pcs;
  • Nut M3 -4 pcs;
  • Screw M3 with cylinder head and internal hex slot:
    o 16 mm – 3 pcs;
    o 20 mm – 1 pcs
    o 35 mm – 3 pcs

In the wicket part, in a hole opposite the magnet stand, an M3 thread is threaded.

description.text:
I recently bought a JGAurora 3-D printer. I thought the rear screen cover needed to be updated to hide the wires and to include a guide slot for the SD card.

I also made a couple of safety covers for the pinch points of the belt and pulleys that move the y-axis.

I use Maker'sGeek filament, so I made a spool hub that fits Maker'sGeek spools.

I made bearing holders for securing the top end of the z-axis ACME threaded rods. These use two 608zz bearings.

I made a tool and parts box that mounts under the print bed. You can actually put one of these on each side, so print two of them.

Printer:

JGAurora

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

When printing the DisplayWireCoverV2, rotate it to print on it's side, using support from the bed only. Once printed, remove the support, and then clip away the top of the wire trough so you can feed the connectors and wires through. I left the top on, but removed the connectors on the ends of the wire, slid the wires through the cover, and then put the connectors back on the wires. Either way works, but don't dissasemble the connectors if you have never done them before or you will likely break them.

When printing the cover with the SD alignment slot and the z-axis cover, they both need to have support enabled to print correctly.

The rest of the prints should print fine without supports. I printed all of these parts with 20% fill and 3 top, 3 bottom, and 3 side layers, and rectilinear fill pattern.

Once printed, remove the support from the DisplayWireCoverV2, and then clip away the top of the wire trough so you can feed the connectors and wires through. I left the top on, but removed the connectors on the ends of the wire, slid the wires through the cover, and then put the connectors back on the wires. Either way works, but don't dissasemble the connectors if you have never done them before or you will likely break them.
I drew all of these objects in Openscad.

author: oroboy

description.text:
The project solves the most common conflict between requirements for operation with multiple camera lenses:

  • Safe and convenient fixing of removed cap of each lens on the camera strap;
  • Safe connection to the camera, preventing the caps’ loss;
  • Fast and simple connection and removal when swapping lenses.
  • All the actions performed quickly and “blindly”, not interfering with the process of photography.

The holder made for my two lenses, mid-long Nikkor 18-105 mm with a filter thread 67 mm and a wide-angle Sigma 10-20 mm with a filter thread 82 mm.

The slider is fixed in its saddle by a dovetail joint and secured by magnet pairs. One side of the dovetail has a half-length, allowing blind insertion of the slider “from up-down” and following its sliding.
The best performance was achieved with opposite orientation of two pairs of magnets on the holder saddle (with respect to the position of the magnets on the slider).
Standard replacement caps with anti-loss strings were used. On the caps a plate with pair of slider saddles was mounted to prevent hitches of the slide on the string’s end in the camera bag. Two saddles allow during swapping of lenses to find any of them blindly, saving the time. One magnet pair is sufficient there.

The kit includes 5 printed parts: holder, 2 plates for caps 67 and 82 mm and 2 sliders for each cap.
In addition need next ready parts:

  • Caps 67 and 82 mm with secure strings;
  • 4 rounded magnets 4x1 mm
  • 6 rounded magnets 6x1.2 mm
  • 8 plastic screws 2.5x9 mm

description.text:
After a few days of testing, I removed the "work in progress" flag and updated the files to the final version.
Some improvements:

  • added a hooking point for accessories, such as carabiners or lanyards
  • aesthetic improvements, as a profile that most evokes the Vespa style and the stylized reproduction of the Vespa GTS Super vent grid
Important:

Print only with flexible filament such as ninjaflex or any other TPU/TPE. Better results you can have with zcory Rubber HS filament.
You cannot press fit the nut in the slot if you use any rigid filament.

To complete the double keys holder and the master key holder, you need an M4x25 allen bolt with a self locking nut.
The Single hey holder needs an M4x20 allen bolt with a self locking nut.

This mount clamps to the headstem of your bike and secures the DJI spark controller as you ride. Use this with Active track so you can control the spark to bring it closer or dodge trees. You will need a small velcro strap. I used this one 200mmx15mm https://www.banggood.com/RJX-HOBBY-Magic-Tape-Tie-Down-Strap-for-RC-Battery-p-1134012.html?rmmds=search&cur_warehouse=USA
You should also attach some 2mm thick foam adhesive sheet to the headstep interface and a small square to the inside bottom of the mount to stop the controller sliding left to right.
Recommend to mount your phone in a separate location on the handlebars using elastic bands or something like a Quad Lock.
I use PLA+ since it has less warping than ABS and seems very strong.

description.text:
Expandable Spool Rack
I created this rack specifically for those 5lb/2.3kg filament spools that our filament usually comes in.
This stand is modular in that you can extend the width of your rack by using longer rod and printing more of the arms.
The arms are also ready for mounting upside down, i.e. under your worktable using M4 bolts. Good for those of us with limited workspace.
OpenSCAD files have been provided so feel free to modify it anyway you like.

Print a minimum of 2 of the arms to hold up a fully-loaded spool. Print more and use a longer rod to put together multiple spools on this rack. You will need to provide your own smooth/threaded rod, and some way to secure the ends so that the spool won't fall off. I had some spare smooth rods and hubs with setscrews that did the job; I expect that allthread and jam nuts will work just fine. x3 M4 trapped nut slots have also been provided per arm, this is useful if you're bolting the rack from under your work table (see photos). This was the original intention of my design, but you can use this as a free-standing rack just as well, as seen in the photos. For the spool hub, garden-variety 608ZZ bearings are recommended for press-fitting into the hubs, which can then be nicely press-fitted into the filament spools themselves. This is probably personal preference, but I find that spools on ball bearings work better for my setup, it minimizes any tension that the extruder has to overcome trying to yank filament off the spool, and lets the extruder concentrate on its job. YMMV. Use a bench vise to get uniform press-fits, a rubber mallet and some careful tapping will do just as well. Print tips:
Using an infill of 15% honeycomb in slic3r works well, you won't need to go denser than that, unless you want a really beefy stand.

description.text:
This is a top bearing mount for P3steel 4.x Z-axis.

Designed for use with M8 lead screw and 608ZZ bearing.

This top bearings prevent Z-axis threaded rods from vibrating while printing with high jerks and accelerations.
Stepper/rods coupler aren't made for taking loads. They compress and uncompress when they want to. This parts take the load from the coupler. Having a huge affect on print quality and layer thickness precision.

print_settings.Notes:: The optional carbon fibre lower plate as said is optional but can be added at any time after build, with it being 0.5mm thick it can be cut with simple scissors and does add a degree of strength and protection to the lower body of the frame even if it doesnt add further rigidity (which imho the frame doesnt need anyway)

description.text:
"Project Sparkie" is basically a culmination of all the design improvements I made along the way while creating my previous designs the "dji spark clone" and "Sparkie" quadcopters.

I took all the beneficial modifications I made to each of these previous designs and balled them all together with new improvements to creat "Project Sparkie"

please forgive the seeming self satisfaction but It was an effort I am particularly pleased with.

the results are a 150mm frame build which offers excellent stability and acro capabilities, coupled with its alarming speed and power its become my favourite creation to date, its an absolute pleasure to fly and so far proven very durable.

the frame itself can accommodate a varied selection of electronics so can be tailored to the builder specifications to a certain degree, Its mounts are spec'ed for 36x36mm sized FC's and can be stacked with a 4in1 esc, it can also accommodate 4x separate esc with careful wiring if the builder prefers.

motors can range from anything as small as 14's all the way upto 22's and are all tilted toward the frames COG which adds to the designs overall stability.

It can use 5" props with minor tip trimming, alternatively it functions excellently with 4" tri's (which is what I use)

The camera is a TX03 Eachine AIO with its clover removed and replaced with a whip antenna.

battery of choice can vary also and would depend on the builders choices, as it stands though my own can use anything from a small 850mah 3s all the way upto a 2200 4s in size, the design has proven very versatile in lipo options.

A basic lipo alarm is also included internally with the connection routed to a plug on the lower plate (see above pictures), not an essential item obviously but handy to have when you get carried away and dont hear your timer going off.

I could continue to list countless variations but the list would get ridiculas so Ill just state my own current build spec's:

Turnigy 2208 2600kv motors
Afro 20amp AIO cc3d fc&esc board
Tx03 AIO cam
Flysky x6b RX
Daldrop indestructables 4045 tri's
3s lipo alarm (also internal)
Lower plate reinforced with a 0.5mm Carbon fibre plate (purely optional and more for looks than anything lol)

Im also including a alternative internal mounting board design for use with Naze32 Rev5, Rev6 and CC3d atom Fc's, the latter is decased and clamped in position (please see above pictures for reference), this board is designed to better accommodate the use of more common 4in1 escs stacked beneath the fc (as appose to the AIO Afro board used in my own version of this frame)

I can confirm the use of alternative board is good as Ive test fitted it with various fc's and Im currently build a second frame using a cc3d atom (see final picture), Ill add completed frame pictures at a later date.

description.text:
Introduction

This is a very simple plate designed to hold an MPX connector in place on the X-UAV Talon (preferrably with wing extensions, but should work without them as well).

These are for the RIGHT side of the Talon, simply print them mirrored for the left side.
To install, simply cut a recess the size of the plate into the wings/extensions and glue them in with the connector already installed.
If you're using wing extensions (like me), install the connector in the plate, guide the wires through the wing and only then glue it in place.

If you have any questions feel free to ask! :)

Version History

  • V1 (15.1.2018)

    Initial release

Suggestions

  • Use an additional wing locking mechanism! (I'll upload one at a later date)
  • Glue in the MPX connectors (after soldering of course) with CA glue first
  • While drying, use clear tape (see picture 1) to hold the plug in place
  • I used UHU POR to glue the holder into the wing

I don't have access to any other PicoBrew model, so I have no idea if it works with the lines of other models.

title: Laser and ABL Connection Board for CR-10 and other 3D Printer

description.text:
CURRENTLY DEBUGGING

I updated the circuit and did a new PCB Layout. V1.6 REV0 is the current version.
Final boards are on their way. Warning: The Pinout of the v1.6 Board has changed distinctly.

This circuit board provides ABL and Laser functionally trough a 6 wire cable to the print head. It's designed for laser modules with separate 5V PWM and 12V work voltage

It also brings down the 12V PWM signal from the part cooling fan to 5V PWM to
connect the laser module PWM/TTL port.
It provides a 12V work voltage with the ability to add a safety switch to prevent laser operation during printer start up. You can also add door switches or an emergency switch so secure the laser operation.
You can optionally connect an external power supply for the laser and ABL sensor.
The board provides an optocoupler for the ABL sensor.
All connections are provided via an 6-pin connector to the print head.

You can mount the PCB to the printer frame with 3mm bolds and headnuts near the Z stepper.

Feel free to provide a nice and snugly printable case. You can bend the LED to point upwards the PCB.

To mount the laser module to the CR-10 or Ender2 use this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757972

Order @ OSHPark:

I used KiCad to draw the circuit and layout the PCB.
Prototype manufacturing with OSHPark.

Circuit

Current challenge: Due to the use of a FET on the CR-10 "melzi" board the PWM signal generated by the Atmel will be transformed to a PWM-GND signal. This kind of signal can not be interpreted by the laser module. It must be transformed to a regular PWM-V signal.

I updated the schematics and add a opto-isolator to convert the PWM signal to the right one. Currently I am drawing a new PCB layout.
Updates following.

Conectors:

ControlBox PWR/PWM:

  • PWR: connects to the power supply (optionally plug external 12V 2A power supply direct to the boards barrel connector)
  • PWM: connects to the second 12V controlled fan port on the CR-10 board

LS Safety Switch:

  • Connect safety switches. Cuts 12V work voltage from the laser if not closed.

To Print Head:

  • 12V working voltage for the capacitive ABL sensor
  • feeds back the ABL Sensor signal to the optocoupler
  • common GND for ABL and the laser work voltage
  • 5V PWM control voltage to the laser module
  • a safety switchable 12V work voltage for the laser

Endstop IN:

  • connects to the old mechanical endstop for safety (not needed)

Endstop OUT:

  • connects the ABL sensor signal to the Z endstop cable from the control box
BOM:
  • 1x LJC18A3-H-Z/BX
  • 1x LM7805CT TO-220-3
  • 12x PC817 EL817 817 DIP-4
  • 1x blue LED
  • 2x 680Ohm resistor
  • 1x 0.1µF capacitor
  • 1x 0.33µF capacitor
  • 2x 3-Pin Header
  • 2x Jumper
  • 3x JST XH 3 angled
  • 4x JST XH 2 angled
  • DC barrel connector (optionally)

You can also solder directly to the pads.

comments.text: From what I understand is that you're using a 12v to 5v power regulator, but from the render you uploaded I have a feeling that the power regulator would shut off or burn from overheating when on full load, would be best to add a heatsink to the regulator.

comments.text:
Hi and thank you for your comment.
The load is not on the 5V its on the 12V rail.
Its about 208,3 milli Ampere (mA) for a 2.5W laser module. The 5V is used to control the power of the laser output.

description.text:
Here is my 100mm / 100g drone. Full HD.
It is extremely fun to fly. I wanted to create a drone that I can fly anytime ; it is so small that it will not bother people in a park or at the beach. It can also handle serious wind and it is so cheap that I'm not afraid to fly close to open water.
Battery is a 2S, I tried a 3S and it's too much power.
RunCam PCB is sticked under the drone, this is a bit stupid in case of a crash ; I'll create a new frame for the runcam split mini that will solve this issue.
No Support needed;
Video of the first flight: https://youtu.be/Z7VXzISYZ4U

Cheers,
BenAllen

title: BullDog Extruder mount with 1:4 speed reduction for 2.85 mm filament (for 3030 extrusions)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are only a few good extruders for 2.85 filament found on this website but none of the ones I printed did work well enough for me. I decided to look what stuff I had laying around (as I did not have the time to wait for new parts) and designed a simple mount for a NEMA17 stepper and the aluminium BullDog Extruder (direct placment of the Bulldog extruder onto the NEMA17 did not work well and resulted in skipping as the filament exerted too much force onto the extruder gear).

The design incorporates a speed reduction of 1:4, this increases the torque required for the filament to be pushed through. The reduction uses a 16 teeth idler and a pulley printed from (Parametric Pulley for toothed belts in OpenSCAD by 0scar). Note the sliding attachment of both the NEMA17 stepper (to tension the 200-2GT-6 belt) and the BullDog extruder (to allow various different extruder gears, e.g. MK8 which I'm using now, the default BullDog gear or the knurled Ultimaker extruder gear). Note that this will also give support to 1.75mm filament! The offset for the BullDog extruder is set by 2 horizontal screws in the vertical mount (this uses 2 brass 5x5xM3 knurled brass inserts).

Two more knurled brass inserts are used in the top mount to secure the lid that holds the 5mm shaft and its bearing in place.

Parts list:

  • 200-2GT-6 belt
  • 16 teeth idler pulley for 5mm shaft of NEMA17
  • 64 teeth idler pulley
  • a 5mm shaft (make some flat spots on it to secure the extruder gear and the 64T idler wheel)
  • 2 695 ZZ bearings (5x13x4mm)
  • M3 screws (various sizes 8, 12, 14mm), washers and (lock)nuts and 4 brass knurled inserts

Note that at the time I had only pneumatic fitting with 10 mm diameter threads, so I designed a small mount (BulldogCoupling6mmTubeHolder.stl) for using those instead of the 6mm threaded ones that fit the BullDog extruder natively.

title: Rock-solid E3D V6 mount for CR-10 with 12mm ABL sensor support

description.text:
Since I would like to change my CR-10 hotend to a more reliable one in terms of clogging (my PTFE tube alway melts after printing ABS at 250 degree) I've decided to go for an original E3D V6 hotend. OK, it's not the cheapest solution but in terms of construction it really convinced me since the PTFE tube is not going straight down to the heated block but ends in the cold zone of the hotend.

So I was looking for a mount that allows me to attach my new hotend to my CR-10 and lets me add an ABL sensor in addition. Unfortunately I could not find any that was working for me. Some were too bulky, some had some construction issues and some simply did not support ABL or the ABL holder was too weak.

Therefore I've started to build one from scratch which can be found attached. It fits very well to the CR-10 plate and is easy to print (just print the STL files as they are. The mount.stl probably might need some supports to be printed well).

Also the construction is rock-solid - no shaky ABL sensor and no movement of the whole construction.

The ABL Sensor has been placed as close as possible to the nozzle so measurement discrepancies should be as low as possible if the bed is a little uneven. For ABL I've used the following capacitive sensor: Heschen LJC12 A3–5-Z/BX.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Use ABS because of hotend temperatures. Some supports might be needed for mount.stl.

The mount had been designed in 123D Cad. Used the sensor and the E3DV6 hotend as reference and also did some trial and error when designing the whole mount.

The first design was trying to get the sensor as close to the hotend as possible and to have a minimalistic design - anyway, it failed because the sensor was not getting close enough to the bed.

The second approach was much better since the sensor height was perfect now and a cable clamp had been added. However, when trying to mount it to my CR-10 I've noticed that the roller screw was preventing the attachment on the mount.

1st attempt 2nd attempt

description.text:
Buenas CMAKERS!

Os presentamos un proyecto que en un futuro cercano formará parte de un proyecto mayor que llevamos entre manos. En este caso se trata de una casa iluminada con leds. Los leds se encienden cuando la iluminación es baja (es de noche), gracias a un sensor de luz. En el interior lleva un arduino nano, una protoboard, 3 leds de colores y un led blanco. Se alimenta gracias a una pila de 9 V.

Los archivos subidos los tenéis en DXF, para el que quiera cortar la casita en madera, o en STL, para el que quiera imprimirla. Tanto el tejado como la chimenea hay que imprimirla si o si en 3d.

También os dejamos el código programado en visualino, una plataforma que sirve para aprender a programar por bloques, totalmente gratuita y muy fácil de utilizar.

Esperamos que os guste!

print_settings.Notes:: Para imprimir utilizo 70% infill y el patrón "Archimedean" pues es el más sólido y el que me da menos problemas a la hora de despegar la pieza.

description.text:
Update 31/01/2018
To increase the pressure in order to mature the cheeses it's been added a M5_15mm modified Knob from danid87 and a 23 cm Thread rods instead of the former 11 cm short ones. Former 420 grams cheeses where down to 240 grams.

Update 17/01/2018
Cheese making (fresh type) success but for mature or half matured cheese more pressure might be needed. A solution for this is on the making...

I tried to harden the prints (leaving them one our at 110º C in the oven) and they actually got harder, but the shape got distorted and shrank (PLA).

The project/El proyecto:

This is more of a Frankenprint than a remake but I might do a proper design in the near future.
I had this Lekue Cheese Making Kit with no use at all, and I "upgraded" it to a proper cheese press inspired by 00sufs's
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723771/#files
It will make small cheeses of near one pound.
PLA printed.

I flattened the tip and printed resized to 0.729 the "Plunger_flat_tip.stl" ...
...and the plunger plate (https://www.thingiverse.com/download:1161917)

Nut knobs are M5's from Modular Mounting System by yyh1002 (great design too) witch I already knew and work great.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194278/#files

To attach it all I used 11 cm Spring Toggles from a dollarstore/poundshop before I decided to print nut knobs.

I designed the stand and the press plate, but both need further adjustment.

You need force for inserting the nut at the base, I used a small vise to insert it
(Español)
ACTUALIZACIÓN
El queso tipo fresco sale muy bien, pero para hacer quesos madurados o medio maduros quizá se necesita más presión sobre la prensa. Estoy elaborando una solución para ello...

Intenté endurecer las piezas en el horno (110ºC durante 1 hora) y, aunque salieron mucho más duras, encogen y pierden algo de forma (en PLA).

EL PROYECTO
Más que un remake es un impresión-puzzle pero no descarto rediseñarlo en el futuro.
Tenía este Kit para hacer queso en casa de Lekue por ahí tirado y decidí convertirlo en una prensa de queso de las de verdad después de ver la de 00sufs.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723771/#files
Como resultado saldrán quesos de unos 420 gr.
Está impresa en PLA e hice al 79,2% más pequeños el "Plunger_flat_tip.stl"...
... y el "Plunger plate.stl" (https://www.thingiverse.com/download:1161917)

El cubretuercas es una métrica 5 del "Modular Mounting System" de yyh1002, que ya conocía y me gusta mucho como queda.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194278/#files

Para fijarlo todo a la base utilicé inicialmente 11 cm Spring Toggles (tornillos para falsos techos) de un todoacien pero luego decidí imprimir los cubretuercas.

Diseñé la base y el plato de prensa, pero ambos necesitan ajustes posteriores.

Se necesita insertar las tuercas en la base, yo uso una pequeña presa.

title: Arlo Pro Camera Mount - boot compatible

description.text:
A 2-axis camera mount for the Arlo Pro series cameras. These cameras have a magnetic and 1/4-20 (1/4 bolt, 20 tpi) mount. The magnetic mount is really convenient.

Additional hardware is needed. A "drywall screw" is used to fix the mounting to a surface. 1/4-20 bolts are used for the rest. A 1/2 inch long round-head carriage bolt is used for the camera magnetic mount. A 2-inch bolt is needed for the ball-mount axis. One 1 1/2 inch bolt or a hex-drive grub screw is needed to hold the camera through the teardrop slot if you go that route. Note that a tight fit around the bolt is required since there are no threaded fittings.

Notes:

Note that when hanging the Arlo camera, the part is not used in compression, but in tension. Use thick walls and/or high infill to ensure layer-layer adhesion. A short acetone vapor treatment or acetone slurry might further help with structural strength.

You might want to paint or use UV resistant ABS.

Design was done in FreeCAD (associated fcstd files included). Originally the box was much deeper (10mm rather than 8), but I lowered the profile to streamline it.

The top is secured with a series of crenellations which can double as a way to fasten the case to a larger enclosure (think LCD display).

description.text:
I picked up a endstop... and now I cant stop.

Thanks to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1068899.
do what do you want.....

We had some snow here (probably about 6 inches) and the news people were saying we only had about 3 inches which I know they were wrong but since I didn't have a gauge I couldn't argue too much! So I created this snow gauge. It is actually 13 inches tall with marks every inch. I included the unmarked version as well as the embossed version and the original 123d design file. I haven't printed it yet but I am thinking I will print it using black filament and then paint the inch marks and embossed numbers white. On the embossed version, the inch marks are above the actual gauge so if it is just below 3 inches then you got 3 inches of snow. I also made the base so it can be bolted down. If the whole gauge is covered then you got over 13 inches of snow as that's the full height.

title: Driving Training Aid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Say hello to the sock pedals, this simple design will help people who have never driven a car before to understand how the pedals work and what they do.

Simply print them out and use bundled up socks underneath the pedals to add resistance.

You will need some hardware to assemble these pedals and I recommend some hot glue.

You will need to print out 12 of the plates, you will also need

12 x 14mm m3 button head bolts
12 x m3 washers
12 x m3 cap nuts

for the frame and

6 x 12mm m2.5 Allen key head bolts
and a stick of hot glue (optional).

for the pedals.

It would be best if somebody is there to explain to you how to use these pedals, this is a lot safer option than being in the car for the very first time with no clue or an idea of what to do.

The hot glue is to cap off the axle holes once you have put the Allen key head bolts into the body of the pedals, these bolts are used as axles.

i3 Pro B

author: Davidlewtas

description.text:
The LEGO Saturn V rocket is incredible, but I decided what it really needed was some authentic lighting, just like NASA uses on the launch pad. This is a xenon spotlight/generator trailer scaled to match the LEGO Saturn V (1:110) and designed to fit two 5mm white LEDs. Designed in OpenSCAD from the few photos I could find of these things. I suspect these were only used with the space shuttle, but they look too awesome for me to care that much.

I currently have them wired up with some old ribbon cable, but it's much too stiff. I'm going to try magnet wire dropped down through a hole in the light pedestals to see if that will look nicer.

For construction, the wheels snap on to the trailer frame, the yokes snap onto the light housings, and the yokes just sit in the pedestals. Everything else is glued down.

You will need:
4x wheel (black)
1x fender (gray) -- has left and right fenders in it
1x body (gray)
1x generator-base (black)
1x generator (white)
2x pedestal (silver)
2x yoke (silver)
2x light-5mm or light-solid (silver)
2x 5mm white LEDs (optional)

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

25%

title: Dillon to Hornady AP powder cop adapter

description.text:
This is a work in progress. At the time of this upload (1/15/18), i haven't tested it but in theory, it should work. I will be testing it in the next few days but am uploading the file so that anyone who wants to test and help tweak it can.

In a nutshell, Hornady does not make a powder cop with an audible alarm. Dillon does but most of the hacks involve either drilling a hole in the press or grinding a notch in the side.

hot it's designed to work - on the dillon powder cop you remove the pin that touches the baseplate of the press, you attach the main body of the bracket. You then you attach a small bolt into the top of the rod to give it the ability to adjust height a bit. Insert the rod into the bracket body, attach the bottom plate, and made you adjustments to the powder cop level indicator.

i'll update this as it's tested and include pictures/video.

Update 1/18/18
I have tested it and it works. I made a couple of modifications for better fit and durability. You will need to purchase a bit of hardware. if I remember correnctly this is what i used

2 - m3 bolts (about 10 mm long long. one needs to have a flat base as it will need a washer)
2 - m4 washers (they didn't have m3 washers)
1 small cotter pin

This is a free design for personal use but not meant to be sold. Id you wanted to send a few bucks via paypal for the design (and for helping you not blow yourself up), feel free to send to [email protected]

update - I also added a rod that has cotter pin holes with some vertical adjustment

UPDATE - I have run about 2k cases through it and it works perfectly once it's adjusted properly. Once the bottom plate and rod are adjusted properly, then you just need to adjust the alarm plunger that came w/ the Dillon alarm to each specific load you're using. I have run it on stations 2&3 of the Hornady LNL AP press.

title: Large filament spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a spool holder for the larger reels we have at our local hackspace and tried a few of the existing models here. I thought they were all a bit over complicated, so created a simpler design that builds the bearing axles into the shell.

Only 4 parts are needed to make each roller, plus x2 (608) skateboard bearings. Which means you will need x4 bearings for the pair of rollers.

Simply slot the bearings into the wheels and then lock them between the two sides. It uses friction fit, so some force may be required.

I used Innofil Pro 1 PLA for the print as it's a lot stronger than plain old PLA, but prints really well.

The city of Blanos is a Persian-inspired city on the coast of a great desert in a 5th edition D&D game.

This piece is meant to be used as exposed brick where wall surfaces have crumbled away. Essentially, if you are building a wall out of basswood or some other material, you can damage and weather it, cut away a section, and glue some of this brick behind it to show where the underlying brick construction is showing through.

These prints are larger than you would need for most exposed brick sections and you can cut, break or otherwise reduce down the size of a single chunk to fit the hole you've made.

Parts Required!

  • 1-1/4" Sheetrock screws

Sorry, I cannot afford to confirm that all of these amazon items are perfect for this project at this time, but from the information provided, they should all work. Let me know of you have any issues!

Print Settings!

  • You NEED to use a TON of supports for the propeller blades!

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??

  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project with this, But the most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2D7YxzV

  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them!

description.text: if it don't fit, try to upscale a little.
Just toying around with an Art Deco styled barrier for miniature wargames. Having some issues printing it out, so it is a work in progress.

Wall Outlet shelf v2

Version 1 available here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1587498

Version 3 available here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2759046

An intrepid space probe on its seven-year mission to return a sample of the asteroid Bennu, this is the OSIRIS-Rex spacecraft. It is working towards some very famous days yet to come, so you'd best print out a copy of this model to follow-along as the mission gets exciting.

This is an original from-scratch design, modelling the spacecraft in such a way to make it 3D-printable. As space probes have many things jutting out at all angles, designing and printing them is difficult. My rule-of-thumb is they should fit in one's hand, so getting feature sizes to work in a small model can be difficult. There is thus a certain amount of artistic-licence with regards to the design. It is not precisely to scale, but tries to faithfully represent the more prominent instruments across the craft, and look good on your desk.

I hope you will agree that the result is a good trade-off between accuracy and feasible-printability. There are basically six pieces and various pegs to hold things together. See below for a few tips on print orientation and assembly. A two-piece stand is also included for an inspiring display.

A bit of cleanup, a bit of hot-glue, snap the pieces together and you should have yourself a nice desktop model.

The peg-based assembly helps deal with variability between 3D printers. Tolerances will only affect the fit of the pegs in holes. If too loose a bit of hot glue works regardless. If a bit tight, you can easily sand the pegs slightly for a better fit.

Will share a version for purchase from of my Shapeways Store in the future for those without the 3D printer (and the patience) who want to just buy and assemble a finely detailled model.

Check Out Some of my Other Space Probes

  • Cassini probe to Saturn
  • Sputnik, the first satellite ever

The assembly should be self-explanatory. There are pegs to hold on the main antenna and sample return capsule. There are also pegs to hold together the top and bottom halves of the craft's main body.
There are also pins to hold on the solar panels. Those pins are best printed flat, rather than standing up. (They're flat in the STL file). Small items printed vertically can easily break where layers separate, but laying flat they'll be fine.

Depending on your printer (mine's a cheapo) use of supports may have acceptable or nasty effects on the supported edge. The design tries to take that into account.

The main antenna dish is best printed on edge (as in the STL file layout) with supports enabled to get the nicest detail on top. The pins and panels all print without supports. The top and bottom chunks should have supports to the build plate for best results.

A bit of clean-up with an exacto knife is a good idea (careful - don't poke yourself) - just to remove stringing and blogs, again depending on how good your printer is.

Don't clean up the pegs too much until you try them. Some blobs and roughness can help if you are doing a 'friction fit' allowing you to remove bits.

I used hot-glue to assemble my pieces with good results.

The solar panels rotate nicely into any desired position. Flipped up, they are as the craft was placed in the launch rocket. Deployed out fully, they emulate the cruise position. Careful not to force them too far. If you like them in a certain position, but a dab of hot-glue on the pins and squeeze the pin into place (use pliers if you need a bit of pressure).

For the stand - you can use hot-glue to hold the post to the base. Or try a small screw in the hole provided. I was happy with glue. Once that joint is made, you can leave the model just sitting on the top of the post securely, or glue it there too.

This model was designed in Blender, using many, many photos to figure out all the instruments. It's not to scale - so features are suggested rather than scientifically accurate, but should be a pretty good representation of the real thing.

The real OSIRIS-REx has a boom arm that reaches out to sample the asteroid Bennu. Making a robust-enough functional arm to do that seemed difficult at this scale. I may add one later with a bit of 'artistic-license' but for now the instrument is shown but not deployable for better survivability.

description.text:
This is a half-proportional 3x3x7 fisher cube. It is a modification based off a 3x3, and I added a few extra cuts and extended some pieces out.

You will have to use a spare core or purchase one. I used a moyu core from https://thecubicle.us. This puzzle doesn't use springs, but you will need six M3 screws 16mm long. Lastly, if you want to sticker like I did, then you can purchase standard Fisher Cube stickers from the same website above.

I bought two of the side 1 stickers (white and yellow) for the top and bottom of the puzzle. Then I also bought eight of the side 2 stickers (2 red, 2 blue, 2 orange, and 2 green) for the sides of the puzzle. For the inner and lower edge and corner pieces you will have to cut some of the side 2 stickers into thirds. This process only requires an x-acto knife and ruler. I measured the side 2 stickers height to be 15mm, so to cut that into thirds go down 5mm and cut across. Then I used the x-acto knife to round off the corner, which makes it look nicer.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Although I printed without rafts, this setting depends on your printer. For mine, it works best to go without rafts, and instead use a 3mm brim. Also, I used 20% for the infill, but 15% would be fine. I used 0.15mm for layer height, but you can use whatever works for you. NOTE: Even with 0.15mm layer height the puzzle will still need sanding.

What to Print:
For the TopCenter and TopCenterCap pieces print off 2 of each, and for the MiddleCenter, MiddleCenterCap, and MiddleEdge pieces print off 4 of each. Then for the LowerEdge, InnerEdge, TopEdge, LowerCorner, InnerCorner, and TopCorner pieces print off 8 of each.

After printing all the pieces, you can assemble the puzzle and it will work, but if you want to improve the turning take the time to sand each piece. It will make the puzzle turn smoother and catch less. It also helps the stickers adhere to the puzzle better.

To design this puzzle I used Onshape, which is an online CAD program. Here is the link to it https://cad.onshape.com/signin, and I highly recommend using it since it's extremely powerful and easy to use.

If you have the RealAcc QAV-X 210 quad, it's challenging where to put an LED light bar on the frame. So, I just had to chomp down at the bit and design this piece which slides onto the read stand-offs and also requires you to screw them onto the rear stand-offs on the belly of the quad for extra support. description.text:
This is an upgraded version of my other Thing - Peptide Backbone.

Printing these pieces allows the user to quickly assemble simple peptide backbones with aliphatic side chains (e.g. glycine, alanine, valine, leucine, isoleucine, leucine). The fixed and rigid atoms are fused together into single pieces, while rotatable bonds are represented by pegs and 1/8" ID tubing, allowing the user to rotate the bonds to form secondary structures (alpha helices and beta strands).

title: Russian Doll Maze Puzzle Box FIXED

description.text:
This is a multiple level maze puzzle box. i.e. you solve one puzzle, and find there is another and maybe another before you finally get to the middle and the prize.

I have included a three part box (two mazes) and a four part box (three mazes) to download and print. They should have clearance enough for a makerbot (let me know if not). I have also included a short four part box so you can test clearances, etc.

However, as before, I have a maze generator that produces the OpenSCAD which is unique every time - so a different maze to everyone else's, and allows you to make them in any size.

The examples I have posted are made using these:-
(Please LIKE this thing if you download)

http://e.gg/puzzlebox.cgi/30/20/o Inner box
http://e.gg/puzzlebox.cgi/30/20/i Outer box, and lid

http://e.gg/puzzlebox.cgi/75/15/5/oo Inner box
http://e.gg/puzzlebox.cgi/75/15/5/io Next box
http://e.gg/puzzlebox.cgi/75/15/5/ii Outer box, and lid

The parts on the end of the URL are firstly whole numbers that are the inside height, inside diameter, and extra height on the inner box (in mm).

Then letters, where "i" means there is a box inside this one, and "o" means there is a box outside this one. More "i"s mean mean more boxes inside and the overall size is increased accordingly.

The set of 4 parts is designed around a rolled up £20 note. So 15 mm wide and 75mm high but with 5mm space to allow the £20 to stick out and be accessible when the boxes are finally open.

The possibilities are endless! Credit to my son, James, for the idea of taking my maze boxes one step further - well done.

title: calibration stick
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Use this to accurately calculate the ideal steps per mm for your printer. (X- and Y- Axis)

How to:

  1. Print

2.Measure the length while not removing part from the printbed

3.calculate new steps per mm:
(150mm*current stepspermm) / measured length

4.Put your new steps per mm value into your software.

If you do not understand step 3:
multiply 150mm with your current step per mm value and divide that trough the measured length.
Of course you print it two times, one time to calibrate your x axis and the other one to calibrate your y axis.

title: Smok TFV8 Big Baby Beast - Top piece lock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a lock ring for the Smok TFV8 Big Baby Beast tank. Using this you can ditch the rubber/silicone locking ring they provide for something more precisely made for the tank that won't be slipping off nearly as easily. I've included the source files for solidworks. There are two versions included. The original, only included as a STL and 3MF, and the revised rigged version as a Solidworks file. The ridges can be easily removed in the Solidworks files by either hiding or deleting the Ridges folder. I printed a test fit with Makergeeks Raptor PLA and found it fits perfectly with my rather large tolerance. If you print with TPU or any other flexible filament, you might consider shrinking by 0.5-2% to change the tolerance so it can be a bit tighter of a fit. I will post pictures of the flexible version once I finish the print.

Printer:

Arthurbot Custom Prusa i3 Style

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print with at least 3 solid walls (or around 1mm in solid walls) with 25% infill. There are already supports included in the model that work with multiples of 0.02mm layer height up to .2mm. Print cooler than usual if printing with PLA to allow for the supports to remove a bit easier.

Remove inner support structure

The supports included have a 400 micron (0.4mm) gap between the model and the supports. These require a little bit of work to remove with rigid filament, but should be much easier to remove with flexibles.

title: Everest Gen7 Long bed pickup body mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A single cab truck conversion for your Everest Gen7! Choose from a tonneau cover version, or the version with the funny looking (but somewhat useful) bed! This is the follow on mod to the Short bed mod, which was posted first. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2752743

This is essentially the same modification, but it eliminates the second door. This is accomplished by gluing in a printed door handle plug and placing the body sticker that comes with the Gen7 body over the plug.

See the short bed mod for the install instructions, only difference being where to cut the roll cage, and to move the body cut line one door forward.

comments.text: The stock nozzle is .4mm   it's orientated as it came in the file. I didn't change the orientation because I didn't read any thing about  Orientation and I didn't want to mess anything up by switching it around.  As far as your comment about modeling a vertical wall.. I have no idea what that means. I'm very new to 3d printing .. my print is indeed paper thin. And I was hoping someone with more knowledge than me could tell me what I did wrong..
comments.author: RedcatRacing

comments.text: I don't think there is anything wrong with your settings, at least the ones shown in the picture. I re-uploaded the files in the orientation that I print them. What support settings are you using?
comments.author: RCVoodoo

comments.text: I'm trying it again in the orientation you suggested in your first reply. I'm 17 hours in and my my initial examination (limited as it is while printing) seems to be much better strength to the walls. Actually it's substantially better so far. The first print was like a rusted out dodge ram fender. You could put your finger through it with zero effort
comments.author: RedcatRacing

comments.text: Yeah, that's lookin' good!
comments.author: RCVoodoo

comments.text: Ok. 24 hours and 46 mins later. I must say it came out way better than the first attempt. I did however get a few cracks trying to remove the support ( they were a lot of support)  the hardest part was removing the support from the grove at the tail gate area (or where a tail gate would be)  IF this thing was solid instead of the double wall I believe it would be perfect. The double walls still give it a little too much flex to be rigid enough for rock crawling. I would seriously be afraid to roll this off a rock or down a hill on an accidental tumble.   I believe for just trailing where there is very little chance of a tumble or roll over it will be fine.   And if that X brace was doubled so they were one in the front and back of the arch. Would be even better.  The gen 7 is heavy enough that one solid thud from a full flip back onto the roof will probably do it in.   Over all, i love it. Its awesome. it looks awesome its a great great mod!!  I just wish it was made tougher to handle what a crawler goes through
comments.author: RedcatRacing

comments.text: Yeah, it is solid if you are using a 0.5 mm nozzle. From your picture the other day it looks like you had a pretty small infill area between the walls... bump your infill to like 60%, or print 3 perimeters and you'd be pretty solid. Thanks for the idea on more hoop support!
comments.author: RCVoodoo

comments.text: I hope it's good and strong this is the best mod I've seen for the gen7 by far. And I want it sooo bad.

remixed_from.author: chito
remixed_from.title: CR-10 Heavy Duty customisable modular e3D V6 mount Volcano 5015 ABL

description.text:
I have modified the e3d mount due to the hook snapping when fitting. I have changed it to a bolt on clamp, it is up to the builder to use.
This is a mount for the V6 hot-end by E3D that is stronger and more rigid than some of the mounts that are out there. This mount also comes with an array of possible options for any extra functionality as attachments on the sides.
Sorce Files and description by chito
I have Remixed it to fit the Tronxy X series printers.

The minimum you will need to print out is the body and one of the faceplates. There are a variety of wings for different combinations, additions and customizations.

NOTE: To print a wing for the other side simply mirror the part in your slicer.

Current modules

5015 fan mount
ABL (18mm thread). Offset X:41.5mm / Y:0
5015 fan & ABL (18mm thread). Do not use on left side. Offset X:63mm / Y:0
5015 fan & ABL alt (18mm thread). Offset X:63mm / Y:12mm
BLTouch mount
30mm heatsink fan mount
40mm heatsink fan mount

Printer:

Tronxy X5S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Most parts can be printed with the above settings. For orientation please look a the screen shot in the gallery.

The only part that needs support is the main body that attaches to the x-carriage.

Assembly

Attach the wing of your choice to the body
    1x M3 Nyloc nut
    1x M3 12mm screw

The wings are adjustable in height (11mm total) and should never go past the tip of the hotend. Place the nut down the holes in the body and secure the wing using a screw from the side of the wing

1a. 5015 wing - Attach the Fan
    1x M3 20mm screw
    1x M3 Nyloc nut

You can drop the nut through the top part of the mount and then slide into the nut shaped hole. lineup the fan and secure with the 20mm screw.

1b. ABL wing
Follow the instructions of your ABL. Take note of which side your sensor is, the offset settings are
    5015 ABL wing: X:63.00 mm Y:0
    5015 ABL wing alt: X:63.00 mm Y:12
    ABL only wing: X:41.50 mm Y:0

Attach the body to the x-carriage
    2x M3 Nyloc nuts

These need to be put in place before you mount the body to the x-carriage. Then use the existing screws to screw the body in place. NOTE The stock screws that come with the hotend and x-carriage might not be the best quality. It's optional to replace these. To do so you'll need:
    2x M3 6mm screws
    1x M3 20mm screw

Attach the front plate
    2x M3 30mm screws
    Fan mount 4x M3 16mm+ screws (came with V6)

Insert the top part of the V6 heatsink and attach the front plate to the body with the screws. these should screw into the nuts you placed in the back of the body.
If you're attaching a fan mount, you can use the screws that came with the V6 fan, but you may need longer ones depending on how thick your fan is. Note that these screws have a drilling tread that grips the plastic

Update

Have updated the hook so it is bolt on

title: Horga'hn Remix for Star Trek Cruise

description.text:
This is a remix of the Horga'hn done by Mrcleanr6, geoffro and TimStough (whose reduced polygon/resized model I started with).

Basically, it was sliced up, hollowed out, and a cup created to connect the face and skull (so you can hide your Tox Uthat (or whatever) and a space at the bottom for a medallion to fill in whatever your event is.

It was done and printed just prior to the cruise and was a popular prop. I took many photos of fellow travelers with the Horgon, way to many to fit neatly in the collage picture.

The main photo was taken and signed by Karl Urban (Star Trek, Chronicles of Riddick, Judge Dredd, RED, Lord or the Rings, etc.)

A number of people asked me where they can get one, so I contacted the guys mentioned above to arrange for them to get a cut of any sales.

You may purchase a finished statue from:
Horgon on ETSY

Let them know if you want the Start Trek Cruise 2 or 3 medallion, blank medallion or empty (so you can create your own).

comments.text: Didn't get to go on the cruise, but a lot of friends did! I posted up a link to this in my Trek Facebook group :) https://www.facebook.com/groups/trekkinfans/
comments.author: wargamegeek

comments.text: Yes, it was surprisingly fun.  Lots of energy, even before boarding.  Not sure how my wife and I can go back to "non-themed" cruises after that.

description.text:
This is a minimalist end cap for 21700 Batteries.

Print 1 and the snug fit should keep your positive connection covered.

Print 2, and connect them with a piece of filament between them to provide a safer method of transporting your battery! Use a longer piece, and you can put the caps on and twist for a tighter fit.

File contents:
Single 21700 cap with notch for filament piece

Filament hole tester -
Smallest to Largest : 1.8mm, 1.9mm, 2.0mm, 2.1mm, 2.2mm
Everyone's 3D printer has different tolerances, and found that what works for me may be different on another machine, so you can print a small piece and try different Filament hole diameters before committing to an entire job.
Depending on how accurate and fancy of a finish your 3D printer provides, you may want to lightly sand the inside of the cap, to prevent damage to the battery wrap.
It`s a simple pen with a screw as a mechanism for pressing the ball pen refill.

description.text:
My son likes dinosaurs and I wanted more practice cutting things up to make them easier to print. I can't say this is easier to print because I am around 18 hours into printing it with 12 hours still to go. So it probably would have been faster and easier if I had just printed it as one piece. But hey, I cut it up. Maybe it'll be easier to scale now? (up, not down. Tolerances will bone you)

Update: I learned a lot from assembling this. For example, a technique I was using during the process of cutting up the model caused the cracks in the model to open and become difficult to seal. I am very unhappy with how the supports were in this model. I also have a lot of print difficulty that may be cheap filament and cold weather, but could also just be poor design.

Things I could have done better?
-The foot pegs are too big and poorly scaled.
-the body seams don't close up well. A dorsal cut might have been a better choice.
-I used the "make solid" command in meshmixer too many times and it caused parts to shrink away from each other and ruin the fit.
-feet needed to be keyed to the leg they go to.
-I cut the legs too close to the body and this caused some thin parts.
-I think my print times were double what they would have been if I had just sent the model to print with supports and no modifications.

Things I was very happy with
-The tail and head both printed very well in the orientation I chose.
-The "solid" body (20% infill) feels better and was easier to assemble than the hollow body (3mm wall) I did on the deathclaw.

I call this done. What's next?

print_settings.Notes:: These knots are messy to print on an FDM printer but possible with support, except that supported areas are often marred. The figure eight knot is nice to fidget with as its nicely springy (in PLA).

description.text:
Knots created by combinations of sines and cosines are common and generalise to produce curves which can be quite complex. Loop crossings can be interleaved in simple knots with carefully chosen sin/cosine functions but these are only approximations and often need large amplitudes to ensure crossing don't interset..

In these designs, the interleaving is done by computing the crossing points and then using a segmented cosine function in which each half-wavelength is equal to the 'length' of the curve between crossings. This gives a uniform separation at crossings so that many more configurations can be constructed with uniform interleaving. 'length' here is measured by the angular difference in the independent variable t.

The OpenSCAD scripts are generated by an interactive tool which currently supports several functions including 3 term sin/cosine functions and Lissajous curves.The parameter values to be adjusted using sliders for speed up update, crossings computed and SVG and OpenSCAD generated. The curves are represented as an array of points in the openscad so the shape cannot be changed but the rope radius, resolution, vertical scaling and other properties can be changed.

To generate these objects, try http://kitwallace.co.uk/3d/knot-braid.xq but beware that it is a work-in-progress.

See my blog post http://kitwallace.tumblr.com/post/169901554274/uniform-interleaving-of-parametric-knots for details

Printer:

Reprap Mendel

remixed_from.title: FatShark Attitude v3 Diversity Cover (Realacc RX5808 Pro)

title: Eachine Pro58 cover Fatshark Attitude V3 V4

description.text:
Eachine produced a new FPV receiver for Fatshark goggles called Pro58. It incorporates an STM32F1 processor which can be used to with different firmwares.

Main information source is on RC Groups https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2904311-Eachine-PRO58-RX-Diversity-40CH-5-8G-OLED-SCAN-VRX-FPV-Receiver

Unfortunately the module bay on the Fatshark Attitude V3/V4 is a bit to small to accept most of the Dominator receivers. With a small bridge build from pin headers you can fit at least the Eachine Pro58 to the Attitude V3/V4 googles without grinding or milling.

BOM:

  • 1pc. 9 pin (male) curved header pin 2.54mm spacing
  • 1pc. 9 pin female header 5mm high version (normal is 8/8.5mm) 2.54mm spacing
  • 1pc. This 3D Printed STL :))

Modification steps:

  • Mount the curved header into the socket of the goggles and mount the female header on the Pro58
  • Put the module on the googles. The module pins should be app. between the curved pins (sorry no picture) and the plastic parts of both header sould have contact.
  • If so, remove the module and bend the pins slightly into the direction of the corresponding curved header pin. Check once again.
  • If satisfied, apply 2 drops of super glue CAREFULLY to curved header plastic and install the module. Wait until the guled cured and remove the unit. Now glue the complete plastic together.
  • Solder the pins together.
  • If using Achilles FW https://achillesfpv.eu/ you can add the OSD mod on the back side. I added a small Picoblade cable for upcoming updates also.
  • Reinstall bridge and module.
  • Cover has a slight fit. Apply some doubled-sided tape between googles and cover, if needed.

Enjoy this FPV receiver on your Attitude:)

Printer:

Mendel90

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm or less

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Test print done with PLA and ABS without problems. Print with the flat side down. I always use a raft.

description.text:
here are some parts for a mini greenhouse used to fruit mushrooms this design works really well for shiitake.
it should work well for oysters as well with the mini fan running all the time

the fan bracket is for 40mm 12v cpu fan

the FAE fan mount is for 120mm 12v cpu fan i run a cheep 38cfm fan blowing out on timer

humidity mount fits 48 x 28.5 x 15.2mm like this one
https://www.ebay.com/itm/BK-Mini-Digital-LCD-Indoor-Temperature-Humidity-Meter-Thermometer-Hygrometer-u/252469750511?epid=1182178365&hash=item3ac85eaaef:g:0rwAAOSwFqJWihmM

cycle timer mod someone elses work i found them at home depot for like $3
https://youtu.be/M3IIj2l1zXk

40mm fan blows up into 1 1/2 scg 20 pvc one inch space alows for venturi effect and runs 100% of the time to keep air from getting stale around mushys if you add a light like i did you only want your humidity around 85-95 or you will get condensation near the fan when your light shuts off and the temp in the greenhouse drops a little
The humidifier is directed toward top of pvc so it is taken directly into the air stream

FAE and Humidity mount is glued to greenhouse plastic with "shoe goo" then cut out holes in plastic

remixed_from.title: CR-10 Heavy Duty customisable modular e3D V6 mount Volcano 5015 ABL

title: CR-10 magnet mount for e3d, volcano, cr-10 stock, remix of heavy duty

description.text:
Update2: 01-Mar-2018

removed salami wings without fan fixation points.
Added salami wings with fixation points. with ABL, too.

Update1: 07-Feb-2018

Changed from WIP / beta to released.
It is proven functional. :-)

Single parts that are new/untested/beta/alpha/pre-alpha/... are named accordingly in the files.

'salami' part has been added.
This part sits between base and swap. It offers support for 'salamiwing-left' and -right.
So you can mount the part cooling fans near the base and only swap the swap, carrying hotend and heatsink fan, etc.
So only two 5015 fans are needed... Not two for every swap part.
With salami you now have the choice to use the standard 5mm cubic magnets or 10mm x 5mm magnets. Even cylinder ones. :-)
I rate it "beta" since no one but me has tested "salami" so far:
beta_cr-10_magnetmount_V0.02-salami.stl

The wings that attach to "salami" are alpha... until now there is no fixation point for the fans.
I plugged the fan in and it keeps it position. Added a zip tie and seems to be ok.
But there will be an improved version with fixation for the 5015 fan.
Files:
alpha_cr-10_magnetmount_V0.02-salamifan_right.stl
alpha_cr-10_magnetmount_V0.02-salamifan_left.stl
Alpha because I have them in use and are fine... but not final yet.

And one wing for salami with ABL:
pre-alpha-salami-abl-wing-left-cr-10_magnetmount_V0.03-test.stl
untested and without fixation for 5015... see above :-)

Longer hex-bolts for 'salami':
cr-10_magnetmount_V0.03-13mm-hexbolt-for-salami.stl

pre-alpha: Added support for NF THC-01 3 color hot end. --> get lift part named:
pre-alpha-3color-lift-cr-10_magnetmount_V0.03-test.stl

Please test and give feedback :-)

initial: 15-Jan-2018

The thing is work in progress.
It will change. Be sure.
Maybe it will change that much that it might be incompatible with an earlier version...
See it as beta phase.
You agree with that ?
Perfect. :-)

This is my remix of the fantastic CR-10 Heavy Duty customisable modular e3D V6 mount Volcano 5015 ABL found on #Thingiverse https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2494642

To make it even more versatile I added some features that came into my mind:

  • magnetic attachment for quick swap between different print heads
  • ‎height adjustment of heatsink to support different types without the need of re-leveling of heatbed.
  • ‎support for creality cr-10 original heatsink. (as well as e3d clone and volcano)

Additionally you will need:

  • 5mm cube neodymium magnets (12pcs)
  • Some M3 screws and nuts

The parts are:

base
This is attached to the carriage with 2 screws. Stock screws may be too long.
It carries up to 6 magnets and up to 4 hex bolts.

hexbolt
It is used to make the whole thing fit tight and wiggle free.
Print up to 4 pcs. I use 2 pcs.

swap
It carries up to 6 magnets and connects to the base like magic.
Insert some M3 nuts (normal ones... I do not have nylock nuts... So they won't fit)
You may attach fan wing mount from heavy duty mount.
swap carries the next piece:

lift
This is where your heatsink connects to.
Insert two M3 nuts.
Attach your original cr-10 print head...
Or turn it upside down and connect e3d clone or volcano.
Slide it in the swap... This way height can be adjusted.
If height fits, tighten it with up to two 8mm (?) M3 screws from other side of the swap.
If you are not confident just use glue.
Mine did not move even with only one screw attached.

For e3d and volcano you will use the 40mm cooler fan mount of heavy duty.
For cr-10 original you may use this one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2184575

The parts are already positioned ready for print.
Support 'from build plate only' may be better. Or full support (but bridging should do well)
I accidentally printed the 'swap' without support...
Not beautiful but functional. I was surprised that cr-10 can print into the air. ;-)

0.2mm layer height.
I used esun PLA+ filament.

In 'base' you will find a vertical element inside one of the hex holes... It is used to make it printable without support.
This can be cut out with filament cutter pliers after the printing.

Things to come in the near future:

  • Part cooling fan mount at the base... The 5015 fans are too expensive to have two on every sub 5 Euros swapable print head. (depends... I learned that there are sub 1 Euro 5015 fans...)
  • strain relief for wires at swap part.
  • ‎different swap parts for attachment of laser, knife or other tools.
  • any ideas and suggestions ?
    Feel free to drop some lines in the comments.

Printer:

creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

80

Notes:

esun PLA+

In 'base' you will find a vertical element inside one of the hex holes... It is used to make it printable without support.
This can be cut out with filament cutter pliers after the printing.

Put all pieces together like in the pictures.
see notes in the main part :-)
