description.text: Scanner ears for the B9 robot. Primed in gray but need sanding.

Printer Brand:

DAGOMA

Printer:

Neva

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

solid

Torque Capabilities

Please know that i designed this gearbox for a demonstration model so that it would be easy for everyone to understand how a compound planetary works, for that reason i omitted the 3rd module that increases the torque capabilities.
Because of that, this gearbox cannot handle much load.

How This Works

  • 60 Turns of the input sun gear will result in ring gear #2 making one full rotation in the opposite direction.
    These are designed to be able to mount them in series on the channel, or drive them with the included stepper motor mount. You will need to scale the channel longer if you want to use two gearboxes and the stepper motor mount on the same channel, but keep in mind it is very boring to watch the second gearbox rotate, as it is very slow.
  • This gearbox can not be back-driven, every piece of plastic on it will snap before you get the input to turn.

Compatibility?

  • This gearbox is the the exact same form factor as my 1379:1 gearbox, and the 100:1. The mounting channel and back cover are EXACTLY the same parts but keep in mind that the gears themselves are incompatible.

Gears Used:

Planets: 6

  • Planetary Gearset #1 (Input End) Tooth Module = .8730

    • Sun = 29T
    • Planets = 16T
    • Ring = 61T
  • Planetary Gearset #2 (Output End) Tooth Module = 1.8707
    • Sun = 13T
    • Planets = 8T
    • Ring = 29T

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??
  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project with this, But the most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2B4BlRn
  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them, I'll link to them and possible create a collection for all of them!
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Gearbox Projects, Don't forget Subscribe to Gear Down For What?! https://www.youtube.com/c/GearDownForWhat

Thanks!

description.text:
When I was doing "larger prints" on my DIY Anycubic Pruse I3, the cord that powers the Ultrabase heated Bed would drop into the lower area and tangle the belt, tap the micro switch, or Bind up the base on it's return.

I create a ramp that slides over the end Printer end cap right in a pre-made groove. The cord now slides (and is guided) along that unit.

title: CTC Prusa i3 Extruder Upgrade Mounting Bracket

description.text:
An x-carriage mounting bracket for a clone of a Geeetech spring loaded extruder. This is so that the extruder upgrade can be fitted to a CTC i3 (Prusa clone) in a direct drive format. The original bracket has holes which sit too close to the x-carriage for these cheap extruder upgrades to fit, so this deals with that problem. Not sure whether or not this would fit an original Geeetech extruder but I imagine they are the same morphologically.

EDIT Actually, the original extruder is better than this upgrade, in my experience, just needs a little TLC. Most notably for me, the screws attaching the fan to the extruder/motor block shouldn't be too tight. I find it's best when they're tightened up fully then backed off a turn or two. Aslo, erring on the hotter side with the nozzle temp seems to help. I know that others have struggled with this extruder but it's been fine for me so far.

Printer:

CTC i3 (Prusa Clone)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Layer height used was 0.25 mm with 0.4 mm nozzle. Printed in the PLA that came with the printer.

title: Galaxy S7 & S7 Edge w/case Phone Holder for desk

description.text:
This is a Samsung Galaxy S7 or S7 Edge phone holder. It is made to hold an S7 that has a case on it to give the phone a total thickness of around .400". There is a sound port that will channel the speaker forward to the direction the phone is facing. It is stable and will stand on its own when touching the screen, however the more you push the more it will eventually tip, so I recommend light touches or the use to double sided tape.

In the design, the 2 extra supports to stabilize the stand in the back, are cut out on the bottom to hold in place a cable that might run along the desk or up against the wall. Also my wife suggested a simple thing called 'Glue Dots', they are removable and leave no residue, but WOW do they work. I suggest using them under this on any surface and it will NOT move.

The middle cutout in the back upper area is incase you have a pop socket attached. :)

*also I see that I didnt save it the correct way, just rotate it in your software. Print it large flat side down for best reults.

description.text:
This remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301 adds two holes and matching pegs. One fits a standard hex bit mount, the other fits a 3.5mm headphone mount, giving some commonly available items to compare with. If properly calibrated, the two pieces will fit each other beg-to-hole and U-to-U.

The STL files come with three variations of tolerance added: 0, 0.1mm and 0.2mm. I didn't get the 0-tolerance pieces to fit until I changed the Perimeter setting in Slic3rPE to 65%.

Printer:

Mendel90 Sturdy

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

comments.text:
Hello,
Thanks a lot for the model. I printed it to check the accuracy and the straight part fits after using some elbow grease. I later checked the CAD file and realized that it should not fit as it is not possible to fit a 3mm object in a 3mm hole. The file should be modified to include some tolerances and typically 0.2mm on average should be added.
Best.
comments.author: zafff

comments.text: With a perfect printer, you can fit a 3 mm object in a 3mm hole, by definition. I got to that after reducing my Perimeter setting in Slic3rPE. I've added a tolerance parameter to the OpenSCAD file, and uploaded versions with 0.1 and 0.2 mm tolerance. See how close you can get.

description.text: This is a simple wall mount for the PS4. There are 2 parts, the bigger one is stronger and is designed to hold the weight of the PS4, while the smaller one has a hole to secure the PS4 (PS4 has a small hole on the bottom for the M3 screw) to prevent it from sliding. It is designed so that PS4 will slide in from the side when everything is mounted on the wall. Unless, you decide to add RGB strip on the back. In that case, you will have to put the strip on the very edge of the PS4 to allign it with the designed holes and place the top holder on the very edge (or not screw it in all the way to the wall and just let it slide up-down) and tjust magically slide it in depending on how you mounted the RGB strip. Anyway, if you don't intend to use the RGB strip, using this will be pretty straight forward. After printing,

Notes:

I tried to design this to use as little support as possible, but some support might be needed for the smaller part. I printed it using PLA, with 4 walls and 50% infill. You might be able to use less infill, but I was worried about the strength, since I don't want my PS4 falling and breaking.

Using this light some details and areas may still be hard to see, like directly under the nozzle, but I designed it for checking on prints. Either checking in person or via the webcam it provides plenty of light, without leaving the main light on, to make sure I haven't been attacked by the spaghetti monster.

Here is a link for the light I used in this design. I'm sure it would work with others, but was specifically designed for this one (link as of 1/15/17).
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LAAUCZ2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I uploaded the lid for the switch box as well as the complete file in case you have tolerance issues, you can scale and re-print just the lid as needed. I did not
include wire holes in the switch box so it could be adapted and placed wherever someone wants. For this particular light, use a 5/32 drill bit to drill the holes.

The nut hole in the brakets is designed for a hex nut, as it's what I had available, but should work with a square nut as well. They may just be a bit more loose until tightened. The screw needed should have a threaded section of 6mm or shorter. The screws I used were 6 mm in total length, 5mm threaded.

I wired directly off the MK3 24v psu for this. As indicated by the product description, it will also work on 12v power supply.

title: Another Y Axis Block for AM8

description.text:
So I'm lazy. I didn't want to undo the Y axis belt tensioner when I moved the parts over from my acrylic frame. I found that the positioning of the parts on the new frame made my belt a little bit too long. Tensioning it would cause the belt to rub on the inside of the Y axis block and bind up.

So I knocked out a little bit of that side of the block. I don't think this will effect the rigidity of the part.

author: EvanTheTerrible1

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Y-Bed GoPro Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It it pretty darn hard to find a good GoPro time-lapse mount for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2 (Monoprice Maker Select, Cocoon Create, etc). So, I made my own.

Recommended pairings:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:507061
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2388134

TinkerCAD has its limitations, and I'm a novice user. If you see room for improvement, remix away!

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7jXkkXGgSAE-wanhao-i3-y-bed-gopro-mount

I liked the simplicity of Luisom77's mount, but it didn't hold onto the version of the Y carriage that came with my Monoprice Maker Select V2.1. Also, the high profile of the vertical post was constantly under threat from my Dii Cooler's protruding blower fan.

So, rebuilt the idea in TinkerCAD with tighter tolerances, wider horizontal bars, a cutout for the Y plate ridge, and a hook tooth to catch the square cutout in the Y plate. The only vertical bit was a GoPro mount swiped from an unsuspecting Ghir0.

description.text:
It's pretty big model, but you can scale it down to whatever size lure you want. There's 2 holes through the model to run a piece of wire down to a treble hook in the back.

With the SCAD file, the pectoral fins are adjustable for attack angle degrees, sweep back, width, length & height. The size hole for the wire to the hook is adjustable too.

I built in some support for the tail and the pelvic fins, but you will need to print it with a brim and maybe some extra supports for the pectoral fins if the attack angle is excessive. Use a cooling fan on full speed and print on tape with a cool bed for best results.

title: HyperCube X-Carriage - Integrated belt tensioner mod

description.text:
First of all, a huge shoutout to both @Tech2C for his amazing printer, and also @bagwan for this cool tensioner mod that I really got to appreciate a lot!

What is this?

This is a modification of the most current v1.2 X-carriage of the original HyperCube by Tech2C, which combines it with the Hypercube easy Belt tensioner by bagwan built right on top, providing additional strength with bulkier walls and pillars, and also fixes a problem with the nut mounting I had with the original carriage for quite a while. (Read below)

Why is this?

So as I said, I love bagwan's belt tensioner, it's really convenient to use and that's exactly what the original hypercube belt tensioning has been missing. Unfortunately, his modification is only held down by 3 screws on top of the original carriage, which to me seems to be quite unstable under heavy belt pull. Hence the bulkier build in this mod.

The other thing which I already mentioned above is that the three nuts you're supposed to insert into the x-carriage, for the screws holding down the belt clamp, at least for me tended to strip and run loose in their mount, making it impossible to screw the belt down tight (and eventually leading to having to print a whole new carriage...).
That is why I modified the mount in such a way that you insert the nuts (I use square nuts) from the bottom of the carriage into a rock-solid mount and as usual screw the belt clamp down from the top. This way, the nuts can't move one bit.

You may notice that my X-carriage mod is just a tiny bit wider than the original (~5mm) but that's not a problem at all, since even the inductive probe mount protudes much further than that.

PPP - Post-print preperation

  1. Drill all holes with a 3mm drill as usual, including the ones of the belt tensioner.
  2. Insert a nut from the bottom of the carriage.
  3. Take a long M3 screw (25mm+), insert it into the belt clamp holes on the top until it reaches the nut from above. When turning the screw, you'll pull the nut further into the mount. For the Square Nuts part, you'll feel slightly less resistance right before the end but screw it in until it can't move any further.
  4. Pull the screw out, proceed with the other two, and then assemble the rest according to bagwan's post.

If you don't have a long screw laying around, you can always get a soldering iron to push the nut in that way.

Things needed / other notes

  1. The hex nuts version is untested so far, please confirm if you print one! :)
  2. You'll obviously need the flat belt clamp printed part and also the half round idler caps, either the long or short ones (I recommend the long ones, though).
  3. You'll need at least 3x M3x20 screws for mounting the belt clamp, and 2 more (or longer ones) for the belt idlers. I use 5 of the M3x20 and it works just perfect.
  4. You'll also need at least 5x M3 nuts, square or hex doesn't matter. You should also be able to use 3x hexs nuts and 2x square nuts, or the other way around. Just print the part for which you have the 3 nuts.
  5. I'd recommend to double up on the zip ties holding the belt on the other side of the carriage. Or use other methods of fixing them, like printed belt clips.

HyperCube

I really like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1862996 but they don't fit on my print bed and I hate gluing/welding things together. This was done from scratch in OpenSCAD to closely match workshopbob's great model.

These are a bit shorter and the pivot point is nearer the center of the skis. This model is also not as sexy as the inspiration as I don't have down a great way to do all the fillets in OpenSCAD. Nevertheless they should work well.

I've printed a set and they look like they will work fine. Flight testing yet to come.

You will likely need some support for the side spacer to print correctly. I'm considering rendering the spacer as a separate part so that this can be printed with no support.

I used .2mm layer height, 7 bottom layers, 3 top layers which will give a mostly solid lower ski. Choose whatever infill you trust above that. I went 25% infill and things seem plenty strong. You will have to print one ski mirrored in your slicer to get a left/right pair.

After printing I placed the tip up to between the first and second cross support in boiling water for 2.5 minutes and then pressed into a frying pan with a bunched up paper towel on top providing pressure into the round edge. I think they turned out well.

comments.text: How successful were your skis? We tried flying our Tundra on the longer Skis you mentioned but the tail wheel sinks so badly it would not lift. The front skids also need alot of tension on the bands. In the end i got it up with the tyres back on, full flaps and having to use a previous snow run we had carved for the tail wheel to run in.

description.text:
Simple flip open covers for the XT60 connectors on a parallel charge board to minimize the risk of shorting unused connectors. Universal fit, use with any board, make as many as you need.

Four different covers can be mixed and matched to work best with your board. By choosing the right combination of opening direction you can make sure your most commonly used balance ports are not covered by the open XT60 cover.

Can also be used to protect charge leads and power leads.

Print in flexible filament - dosnt have to be crazy soft, I find Sain Smart TPU to be perfect for this application.

description.text:
Recommendations:

  • I would recommend 100% infill on the display for a solid grip on the shelf or table. A 10% infill and 2mm wall thickness is more than enough for the clamp screw.

  • Don't change the angle of the models, they are placed that way to optimize the part strength.

  • This model will need supports, just make sure the supports doesn't destroy the thread.

  • A piece of electrical tape on the "ceiling" of the clamp will increase the grip. (see pictures)

  • Don't tighten the clamp screw too much. It might crack the print and won't improve the grip, most likely the other way round.

  • The clamp fits tables or sheves between 12.5 mm and 20 mm thick, I would not recommend to rescale the model. Nofify me if it's too big/small for your shelf and I might modify the model.

description.text:
I wanted a magnetic cup holder for some little plastic cups I use for mixing epoxy.

This is a friction-fit, customizable cup holder. I'm using both the pressure of the wall pressing inwards and the ridge of the cups catching on the individual layers of the print to hold the cups in place. The cups do not drop down to the bottom when you pull one out.

The STL file I provided is set for 12mm by 3mm magnets. The 3mm magnets will be slightly recessed so as not to scratch the magnetic surface and they are a loose fit so they'll need to be glued. If you want to use another size you'll have to use the customizer.

title: Nintendo Switch Phone Joy Con Grip

description.text:
Huge thank you to Clinton Matos for writing an article about this! https://www.htxt.co.za/2018/01/18/attach-the-nintendo-switch-joy-cons-to-your-phone-with-a-3d-print/ Thanks to Ethan Gach for also writing an article about this https://kotaku.com/joy-con-grips-are-a-lot-more-useful-with-smartphones-in-1822269622

This is what gave me the original idea to make this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2435511

This is a switch joy con grip for the iPhone X, iPhone 6, iPhone 6s, iPhone 6s+, iPhone 7, iPhone 7+, Pixel XL, Pixel 2 XL, Note 8, and Galaxy S8+ , and I would love to see some remixes with other types of phones. I would also be happy to add more phone types upon request. This can be used for watching a stream while on a loading screen, having a game map open, accessing the Nintendo Switch Online App, and much more. Printers can vary in their tolerances, so you may need to edit your slicer settings to print it a few percent bigger or smaller to get the tolerances perfect. I hope you enjoy this accessory!

I modeled it using Fusion 360 (https://www.autodesk.com/products/fusion-360/students-teachers-educators download link)

To get the tolerances right I used a digital caliper to get the exact measurements of the components.

title: Modular dual monitor stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Modular dual monitor stand based on metallic tubes OD 25mm with vesa75/100 mount
Recommended length of tubes:
2x500mm vertical
2x300mm legs
4x700mm horizontal (or 800mm for monitors more than 23")
Length can vary, depends upon monitors you have.

Also, you need:

  • m4 bolts and m4 nuts. (will update quantity soon)
  • 4xm5 hex bolts for axis regulation

This project can also be used for 3 monitors setup: rotate central part and use monstand_p6.b instead of monstand_p5.c

Updates:
17.01.2018 Uploaded STEP files

Notes:

For most parts support is not required. Some bolt/nut holes have 0.2mm wall to print in a horizontal position without support.
But for those, I recommend putting support :
monstand_p5.a.stl
monstand_p5.c.stl
monstand_p6.a.stl
monstand_p6.b.stl

Orient each part to print it durable.

Used 4 perimeters/top/bottom and 30% infill

title: Bose SoundSport Headphone Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a clothing clip mount for the Bose SoundSport headphones. The spring-clip they come with was constantly popping off the cord and finally broke in half itself. So I made something a bit more robust. In this design the cord divider is press-fit into the clip with the individual cables held in place.

I've been using it for about two weeks now and I'm still happy with the design. Typically I run my headphones under my shirt so I everything arranged so the clip itself sits on the outside. It's also great because it makes keeping each earphone cord on the correct side.

MP Maker Select Plus

author: EMC2_Trooper

description.text:
Simple small paint cups for mixing samples of paint or for being effiecient.

PLA- nozzle 190, bed 45
ABS- nozzle 215, bed 90 (w/ Davinci Pro 1.0)

See if you can fit the pieces into the snowflake shape (without cheating!).
There are also many other shapes that can be made with these pieces, including a straightforward hexagon - I'd love to see what you can come up with!

Was having so much fun learning BlocksCAD that I wanted to try something else.
As usual, I'm not a great coder and I'm sure this could be done more elegantly but it does the job for now.
I first created the basic hex shape after I discovered that cylinders with small radii produced 5, 6, 7 sided shapes etc. After that I created modules that would then add another hex shape at different positions around the first one with a loop to add more if needed (e.g. pos_1 with no. x).
Then I set up modules to create the different shaped pieces in the puzzle before finally creating a base with the 'hull' and 'difference' blocks.

Everything printed out fairly quickly on my Anet A8 and fitted together OK as I built in a little tolerance for that. After my first print I needed to make the gap in Piece 10 a little bigger to fit the other pieces in but they should be OK 'as is' now.
There is an easy/hard setting (0/1 in the variable). The easy setting produces puzzle pieces that can only be one way up, the hard setting means that the non-symmetrical ones can be flipped over. I have only provided stl files for the 'hard' setting, I think the 'easy' ones may need to printed slightly smaller to fit in the base.

Please let me know if you print this out and send me any pictures of fun or unusual shapes you can make!

Note: I am not the inventor of this puzzle - it is one of the many geometric puzzles designed by Stewart T Coffin

Printer:

Anet A8

title: Radiation shield sensor mount/weather station controller

description.text:
I must start by saying that this is a work in progress. I have not completed this project as of yet, but will in the future. Feel free to use these things to create your own weather station. This is also just one piece of an entire weather station I am building. The full station has sensors for wind speed, wind direction, 8 inch rain gauge, temperature and humidity. This documentation may be heavily modified in the future.

This model is to build the radiation shield which houses the temperature and humidity sensor in the top shield area and the main controller for the weather station in the base.The radiation_shield.scad file can be modified for all pieces of this build.

Printer:

Anet A8

Notes:

There should be no need for supports except for the base as it has the pipe mount out the side. The top layer, middle layer, sensor mount and base parts should be printed top side down. I printed this using eSun white PETG filament. I had read that the eSun filament had some UV resistant chemicals in the plastic which I figured would help with the longevity of the sensors as it will be out in the sun and other elements.

I designed this radiation shield from looking at designs of other radiation shields on thingiverse and on the web. I did my own customization from the pictures and information that I found. Feel free to modify any of the parts on this build. The radiation_shield.scad file was used to create all of the .stl files found in this build.

This is considered the main part of the weather station as it houses the main controller for the station. The radiation shield portion of this build houses a DHT22 temperature and humidity sensor, but the design of the sensor mount can be easily modified to hold other types of sensors such as I2C temp and humidity, barometric pressure or otherweather related sensors. The station is based on the MySensors framework found at mysensors.org. Most of my work on this has been posted to the MySensors form under this forum thread. The main controller that I am building is built on a MySensors Easy Newbie PCB created by @sundberg84 from the MySensors forum. Many thanks to @sundberg84 for his work on that great board. The base of the radiation shield has standoffs designed to mount the PCB on the under side and is protected from the weather. In the event water should by chance get inside, the bottom cover is designed with a slight taper towards the center where there is a drain hole to prevent any water buildup.

The radiation shield is easily customized. My shield consists of a top layer piece plus 6 middle layer pieces. The entire shield is put together with lengths of 1/4 x 20 threaded rods cut to the length needed to fit through the layer pieces, the sensor mount layer, and the top thickness of the base. The threaded rods are screwed into the 3 recessed holes in the radiation shield top cover. All of the rest of the pieces should then stack together and then get locked in place with 1/4 x 20 nuts inside the base. It would probably be wise to use either stainless steel or galvanized threaded rod to help keep it from rusting.

The DHT22 sensor mount is the tall piece with the cylindrical base. The sensor mount plate has a hole in the side. This hole should be tapped and used to hold a screw used to lock the sensor in place. If you decide to modify the center DHT22 mount piece to use other sensors, you should print as many radiation shield middle layer pieces as are needed to cover your sensors leaving an adequate gap at the top.

I will document things here as this build gets further along.

At this point I am not going to go into much detail on all of the different parts, but as I get into finishing the weather station build I will update information in here as I get things more to a completed stage.

Check out the other parts of the weather station build:
Tipping bucket rain gauge : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757560
Wind speed and direction sensor : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757369

author: Ricky32

title: Skywalker Lightsaber - Revenge of the Sith
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These models have a few tweaks to CaseStudyno8's Skywalker Lightsaber to make it closer to screen accurate to the version seen in Episodes 2 and 3. It removes the screws from the pommel and changes the inserts to be closer in profile to those used in the movies.

You need six pommel inserts, which can be made by printing the single insert file six times or the inserts with support file once. If you use the file with the custom support, please let me know how easily they seperate from the support (I've tweaked that model since I printed it to make it easier to remove).

The other significant inaccuracy in CaseStudyno8's model is the lack of a rounded boss for the knurled button, but I was not able to fix that easily using Solidworks and Meshmixer.

author: RabidOtter

title: 3D Printed Miniature Glider - Balsa Glider Style!!!

description.text:
Awesome miniature 3D printed glider that is similar to the balsa wood gliders so many of us cherished as kids. Prints and assembles incredibly fast and is fun to fly. Flies amazing and if you catch a headwind just right you can have incredibly long glide time and distance.

Check out our video on how to make them:
https://youtu.be/uy2kXmUjdzQ

We will also post more specifics on our website as soon as possible:
https://www.3d-flight.com/

Important!: We used a .2mm nozzle and the wing and fuselage are done with single outer layer because we wanted them to be really light and keep the wing loading down. The glider may crack and break but just glue it back together, its quick and easy. They print so quick just print multiple at a time.

Just use some super glue and accelerator (optional) to assemble.
for the weight we taped a fishing weight to the front (2g)

remixed_from.author: buzzkc
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Front Fan Sensor Mount 18 mm

title: Capacitive Sensor Schematic for Anet A8

description.text:
The Anet z limit switch is normally 5v and is triggered when the mechanical switch is pushed, grounding the 5v sensing pin to ground. The Capacitive Sensor works by going to ground when it senses a surface. Basically using two rectifier diodes, the Anet board is protected from the higher voltage of the 12 volt sensor, but allows the 5v z limit switch pin to pull to ground when the capacitve sensor senses a surface.

I'm using this setup on two Anet A8 printers and they work great and repeatably the same every time for the last year. The 12 volt supply to the sensor is a must, 5 volts is not high enough to provide a repeatable reading.

Why 2 diodes? Why not? The second diode is mostly for a backup since we're trying to protect the controller's 5v limit switch circuit from the 12v of the sensor.

Parts needed:
1 - Capacitive sensor (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00542U3M4): Capacitive Proximity Switch; Model : LJC18A3-H-Z/BX; Wire Type : DC 3 Wire Type (Brown, Black, Blue)

2 - Rectifier Diodes (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B008LTJOX6): 1N4004 400V 1A Axial Lead Silicon Rectifier Diodes

1 - 3Pin JST-EH Connector (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00TGSD6PI)

The sensor is mounted in the Anet A8 Front Fan Sensor Mount 18 mm (stl included in this thing): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2111157

Note: When setting up the sensor the first time, I start with the hot end a couple of mm's off the bed and the bottom of the sensor about 5-6mm above the bottom of the hotend. You may need to turn the adjustment screw on top counter clockwise several times until the light comes on for the sensor, showing it's sensed the bed. I will usually raise the hot end about 50 - 100mm or so off the bed, then attempt to home, and wave my hand over the sensor to verify that is is indeed working as it starts to come down for homing Z. If it doesn't stop when you wave your hand under the sensor, you may need to kill power to keep your hotend from driving into the bed

Use at your own risk, not responsible for damage to your printer.

title: Fan Washers for Tevo Little Monster

description.text:
(Updated: printing 4mm version)
I wanted to mount the fan of my Tevo Little monster on the top of my case to leave more room inside. I quickly found that the head of the screws pull through the metal fan cage. These washers are the right size to both keep the head from pulling thorough, and to pull the extra long screw further out of the overall enclosure (hence the thickness).

Feel free to make your own.
Inner diameter: 4mm
Outer diameter: 8mm
Height: 4mm (though I scaled mine to .75% or 3mm just in case).

You will need to print 4. I used a layer height of .3 mm, with 3 top, bottom and perimeter layers. I used 30% rectilinear infil, though I think the perimeters made it solid.

The inner diameter could probably be 3.5mm if you want, but I'm too lazy to change this just now.

Photo is of finished installation. As recommended the fan is blowing into the enclosure (label down). The yellow printed washers keep most of the screw out of the enclosure so as not to catch on wires, etc.

author: abst

description.text:
I based mine on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2387368 but made it 30mm because that suited the screws I had available. Yes it will require longer screws or standoffs to mount the spacers. I used 5mm m3 standoffs bolted to the base. The tower and spacers are then screwed to the standoffs using 30mm m3 screws. You could use different screws/standoffs/nuts, as long as they are long enough to attach the 30mm spacers. The height of the spacers could easily be scaled to different sizes.

I split the original into two pieces. That allowed me to install without unplugging wires, I'm lazy that way.

I simply drilled one hole to re-position the Z axis switch, also lazy, but it works. (Actually I drilled 2 holes, first attempt was too high)

The whole tower is held in place by 4 screws accessible from the inside. Replace those with standoffs/screws the right length to fit whatever spacer you choose to use.

I didn't need to unscrew the motor, just left it attached to tower and raised the whole thing.

Watch the video and photos from the original version. That helped to show what goes where. Then I did my own thing.

title: east3D gecko coreXY Z-wheel-carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Parts Needed.
4x 3d printed z wheel carriage
4x http://openbuildspartstore.com/delrin-mini-v-wheel-kit/
8x http://openbuildspartstore.com/mini-v-wheel-precision-shim/
4x 6mm http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
12x http://openbuildspartstore.com/nylon-insert-hex-locknut-m5/
12x 30mm http://openbuildspartstore.com/low-profile-screws-m5/
8x (M5 washer works also) http://openbuildspartstore.com/precision-shim-10x5x1mm/
4x m6 washers like these. https://www.amazon.com/Steel-Washer-Plated-Finish-Metric/dp/B009OK4VLQ

assembly:
take off the wheels from the cart.
and remove it from the z stage.
insert one 6mm eccentric spacer into each carriage .
screw the new carriages to the carts with the m5x30mm screws. nice and tight.
(wheels are now held inplace with nuts.)
wheel instalment.
copper spacer first then wheel last precision shim. (or a m5 washer works)
last the nut and hold the bolt with the allen key so it does not want to loosen.
put the carraiges back on the z stage.(do not tighten the bolts till the end)
now the mini wheels .
put the M6 washer on the m5x30mm bolt put it in thru the hole a step at a time now put a mini-v wheel precision shim then the wheel then another mini-v wheel precision shim then the nut. tighten up the eccentric spacers to hold the wheels enough . not to tight( you should be able to spin the wheels with slight resistance ) finaly tighten the carriages to the z stage.
(i do advise to relevel and retighten the z belts at this time.)

Here's the gcode I use to pause prints for changing the filament on my i3 v2. I reduce the temp while it's holding, in case I'm not around immediately. Otherwise, it will bake and clog when it sits there at full temp.

; Filament Color Change
M117 Insert Filament

G1 E-5.000000 F500 ; Retract 5mm

G90 ; Set Absolute Coordinates
G1 X20 Y20 F9000 ; Move to hold position
G91 ; Set Relative Coordinates
G1 E-40 F500 ; Retract 40mm
M104 S180 T0
M0 ; Idle Hold
G90 ; Set Absolute Coordinates
G1 F5000 ; Set speed limits
G28 X0 Y0 ; Home X Y

remixed_from.author: hiuwo
remixed_from.title: Mountable peristaltic gear pump, comes with allen key

description.text:
I created this peristaltic pump to automatically water my plant using a soil moisture monitor. I started with the peristaltic pump provided by hiuwo.

It is not quite working. I have found that as the pump turns the tubing will scoot through the pump. There needs to be some features on the end that will prevent the tube from slipping. On industrial pumps I have seen they have rigid fittings, and the tube inside the pump is different from the tube outside.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

BOM:

Standard Continuous rotation servo (mine came from Parallax)
Servo Horn adapter screws
2X M3x12 Screws (pump mounting)
2X M3x20 Screws (sevro mounting)
2X M3 Nuts (servo mounting
Flexible tubing, probably Tygon (1/8 - 1/16 inch) - not working.
Arduino Uno
Breadboard
Wires
LED
100 ohm resistor
capacitve soil moisture sensor - https://www.amazon.com/DFRobot-Gravity-Capacitive-Corrosion-Resistant/dp/B01GHY0N4K/ref=sr_1_sc_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1516069131&sr=8-1-spell&keywords=capacitve+soil+moisture+sensor
Breadboard
USB A-B Cable and USB power supply

Arduino pinouts

Pin 3: Servo Control
Pin 13: LED Anode

LED Cathode > 100 ohm resistor > Ground

A0: Soil Sensor Blue

And then there is servo power/ground, arduino power/ground, and sensor power/ground. I ran everything off the Arduino's 5 volt rail, with power originating from the USB port to a wall.

Assembly

To get good alignment, assemble in the following order:

  1. Free the pump and make sure it rotates
  2. Attach the 4-point servo horn to the servo
  3. screw the servo horn adapter to the servo horn
  4. Place the servo horn adapter shaft into the pump and rest them both on the baseplate.
  5. loosely place the servo screws in the slot, but do not tighten
  6. Install screws into pump (from bottom side) and tighten.
  7. Tighten screws that hold the servo.
  8. Run tubing through peristaltic pump (good luck)
Code

Hosted on Github here: https://github.com/Lars-0/Plant-Watering-Device/

but also here:

/*Plant watering Device.

  • Lars and Ellen Osborne 2017
    */

'#include
Servo myservo; // create servo object to control a servo
int val;
bool dry;
int n = 0;

void setup() {
myservo.attach(3); // attaches the servo on pin 9 to the servo object
}

void loop() {
dry = CheckDry();
if(dry == true){
Water();
n++;
}
else{
n = 0;
}
if(dry == true && n > 10) { // number of times to try watering before giving up.
help();
}
delay(1000); // only read the sensor once every second.
}
void help() {
while (true) {
digitalWrite(13,HIGH);
delay(500);
digitalWrite(13,LOW);
delay(500);
}
}
bool CheckDry() {
val = analogRead(0); //connect sensor to Analog 0
if(val>=430){
return true;
}
else {
return false;
}
}
void Water(){
myservo.write(180); // full speed pumping power
delay(10000); // run for 10 seconds
myservo.write(0); // Servo off
delay(100000);
}

THOROUGHLY RE-FITTED
DEFINITIVE ENERGY / CABLE / DRAG CHAIN.

Backwards Compatible (MK-III, MK-II & MP CABLE CHAIN).

UNIVERSAL MOUNTS INCLUDED FOR MOST APPLICATIONS
MONOPRICE SELECT MINI HEATED BED BRACKET INCLUDED
SAFELY REROUTE BADLY PLACED HEATED BED WIRES USING THE CLAW

+PRINTS AS A 4 PACK. Print and give them a little click to start the chain reaction.
+3 PACK & STARTER LINK ALSO INCLUDED
+RADIAL STOPS to repeatedly limit movement.
+UNIVERSAL MOUNTING BRACKETS INCLUDED
-MONOPRICE SELECT MINI MOUNTING BRACKET INCLUDED

INCLUDES
+Clip together construction prints Easily on monoprice bed.
+What dreams are made of.

NOTE
Very positive engagement.
Pay attention to orientation when clippin together. Not Designed to come apart easily.

ABOUT MONOPRICE SELECT MINI INSTALLATION

INSTALLATION GENERAL
+Fitted Monoprice select Mini Bed Mount, Use existing holes as pilot holes for bed mount.
+Three holes need to be drilled into the back of the cabinet below the bed.
+Open bottom of printer using proper sized philips (star) Screwdriver.
+Reposition wires to prevent wire damage during drilling.
+Use step drill to prevent sudden drill penetration.
+Fit these holes AFTER BED MOUNT and CHAIN configuration.
+If you are doing this repair on a new printer and are just adding wire you can appropriate
heat shrink tubing without the use of solder and still have satisfactory results.
+Glue type tube of 3:1 ratio preferred.
Wires sized appropriately similar will not get very hot in use.

CHOICE OF REPAIR SOLUTION
Install a new heated bed power source and relay or solder equivalent longer wires to the bed or use the existing wires. This is a reasonable route for the wires.
Existing wires connector clips should fit through the chain although if you chose to solder in a few more inches of wire it allows for easy cable threading.

BED MOUNT
+Remove the bed to install the Bed mount.
+Drill the four small holes on back of bed with a clearance hole for your smallest nut and
bolts set of four that's at least 3/8" in length.

PRINTING 'ROOF' OF CLAW
+A Bic hex type ball-point pen can be dropped into the claw chain print as the crest of the
side walls begins to show.
The pen is a good size to support the first layer of the top of the chain.

DO NOT use Skirt or Brim or support as these will mess up the chain. All layer height
setting have worked well on this print.

PREFERRED SETTING INFO
+Prints best as positioned in STL File.
+Glass Bed used in testing models.
Multiple links not recommended without a piece of glass.
+3.5mm or greater retract.
+30mm/sec print speed +/- Depending on quality and ambient conditions.
+Clear Tough PLA or PET-G. Top Range of heat for good layer adhesion.
+NO BRIM / NO SKIRT / NO SUPPORT
+.175 layer height works very well.
+4 mm wall
+100% Fill
+Bic pen (Hex shaped) inserted just before first layer of top of chain to ensure support
without getting in the way of the nozzle.

title: Pinewood Derby paint support
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Paint supports for pinewood derby cars.

  1. Mark drill holes on bottom of car 100mm apart
  2. Drill 1/16" pilot holes (depth depends on car shape - DON'T DRILL ALL THE WAY THROUGH!)
  3. Drill 1/8" hole from pilots (depth depends on car shape - DON'T DRILL ALL THE WAY THROUGH!)
  4. Put car on supports and prime away, heeding all cautions for your particular paint you're using

This is intended for spray priming the car. Any use of brushes will likely move the car on the supports as they're not very strong - just enough so you can spray the whole car.

author: trkracer

title: Valentine Vase Dazzler: Color LED Light Base for Valentines Vase & Flowers

description.text:
Perfect for that special Valentine's Day gift! (Or Mother's Day, birthdays, graduations, etc.)

This base allows you to turn a 3D printed vase into a fabulous light show. Here's a couple of videos with examples of the light patterns:

  • https://youtu.be/cTFc3N4nx0w Uses: Spiral Vase by Yllonnoce and Anniversary Roses by XYZ Workshop

  • https://youtu.be/hQKWgm4H6uw Uses: s: Plus Vase by by BenitoSanduchi and Anniversary Roses by XYZ Workshop

Create awesome lighting effects with ease. Pick an open source vase to set on top and optionally fill the vase with 3D printed flowers if desired.

You can source your own electronic parts or buy a convenient kit from the Vorpal Robotics Store. Please consider supporting us so we can continue to publish great new open source projects.

The base incorporates an Arduino Nano and some controls that allow you to select a lighting pattern and a brightness. There are 10 lighting patterns built in, including:

  • Fades between colors of various hues
  • Flashes and twirling lights
  • Flicker effects like a flame
    Each time you press the pushbutton on the back, the Vase Dazzler cycles to the next light pattern. The potentiometer dial can be used to select brightness levels.

The Vase Dazzler runs on any kind of 9v battery or can be powered from a mini USB cord, see below for details.

Compatible Vases

Any vase that is1.5" to 2.5" (40 to 67mm) in diameter where it touches the table top will work well with this project. If the bottom is more than about 3 inches (70mm) it will also work as long as it's not so large as to be unstable. Of course you may be able to scale the size of the vase to make it fit better. For very large vases, you could actually put the Vase Dazzler right inside the vase.

For best effect:

  • Use a translucent plastic. White or clear translucent plastic works best because then the colored LEDs take over the task of imparting a color.
  • Print with as large a layer as possible to let maximum light through.
  • Print with no bottom layers if possible so the light goes right into the vase. Print also of course with no top layers if you want to insert flowers or other decorations.
  • If your slicer has a "Spiralize" option, that will make the vase transmit more light.

Here are some vases that we've tried, but there are many, many others here on Thingiverse and other sites that should work fine:

  • PlusVase by BenitoSanduchi
  • Spiral Vase by Yllonnoce
  • Cyclodic Vase by scottvader

In some cases you may need to scale the vase to fit.

Power Supply

The kit includes a 9v battery clip. We suggest rechargeable batteries. A 280 mAh NIMH 9v battery will last about 5 hours on a low brightness setting and about 1 hour on maximum brightness (but maximum is overkill for most situations!)

The Arduino Nano's USB port is exposed in the back of the unit, so you may also power it by plugging in a cell-phone charger type 5V power supply with a USB A to mini cord. (NOTE: USB A to mini is not the same as a standard cell phone charging cord which is A to micro. However, A to mini cables are commonly available because they're used in some cameras and video equipment).

Electronics Needed

To help us continue to publish new open source products, please consider purchasing some or all of the parts from our store. We have individual components as well as kits that do not require soldering and have the Nano pre-flashed with the code at our Vorpal Robotics Store.

Parts list:

  • Arduino Nano
  • 12 RGB LED Ring with addressable LEDs such as WS2812B or similar
  • 10k Panel mount Potentiometer, 1/4" shaft diameter
  • 9x13mm rectangular switch (on/off switch)
  • Pushbutton designed to fit in a 12mm diameter hole
  • 9v battery clip and 9v battery (rechargeable battery recommended)
  • Wires, Dupont Jumpers, solder, shrink tube to insulate connections
  • One M3x10 screw
  • 6 foot USB A to mini cord for powering the device and programming the Nano.

Arduino Code

The code is available on GitHub here: Vorpal Robotics Vase Dazzler

The code is pre-loaded on the Nano if you purchase the kit from the Vorpal Robotics Store

Assembly Instructions and More Information

See the Vorpal Vase Dazzler Wiki Page

It is no a model for comercial use and all kind of intention of sell and make business or take profit from it or any derivation remix etc will be punished by the law

Esta solución protesica solo se podrá adaptar en un paciente niño mayor a 3 años hasta los 10 años bajo la accesoria de una profesional de la salud, terapeuta, fisioterapeuta, fisiatra y con la colaboración de un profesional en psicología

Por favor lea cuidadosamente primero el manual de seguridad y uso de esta solución protesica

Biomechanical design: Christian Silva
Conceptual design and modeling: Osce Days Bogota
Improvement and modular development concept: Laurent Perrin

Prosthesis leg children is a project designed and developed by a group of 3 sections Christian Silva student of Doctorate in the National University of Colombia expert in Biomecanica. Model in turn based on the work directed by the Osce Days Bogota group and improved and modularized by the engineer Laurent Perrin in addition to the e_NABLE group, www.enablingthefuture.org Work developed by the e-Nable Colombia-Give me five team, Fabrilab en Bogotá, with the participation and support of Recreartech in the process of 3D scanning and 3D rendering in 3D printing. All these files are covered by the creative license attribution common goods. Non-commercial, please use the reference from us if you wish to print it.

All parents and children were informed about the study and research for the development of this work. For children ages 3 to 10, the consent was explained by the principal investigator and signed by the children and their parents. The written informed consent of the parents was obtained in order to publish the images and videos that appear in the research study and the research. Detailed safety guidelines were given to parents regarding the use and care of the leg prosthesis.

detailed security guidelines link:
http://enablingthefuture.org/build-a-hand/safety-guidelines/

The pieces are printed on flexible materials such as Filaflex and rifidies such as PET-G

Fabrilab www.fabrilab.com.co

This prosthetic solution can only be adapted in a patient from 3 to 10 years old under supervision to a health professional, therapist, physical therapist, physiatrist and with the help of a professional in psychology

Please read the safety manual and use of this prosthetic solution carefully first

title: Another Google Home Mini Outlet Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Let your Google Mini soar while completely hiding the cord! No tools or hardware required, though you can use a screw to better anchor the printed part. If you have dogs, curious cats, kids, or are just clumsy I would HIGHLY recommend using a screw to prevent damage to you wall, speaker, and/or the printed part. I may add a spacer to print for even better stability while using a screw.

The cord folds nicely in to the open area between the outlet and the speaker, just insert the mini b end, plug adapter, and slowly fold the cord in to the opening. Be careful to not bend the cable too tightly so as to not stress the internal wires.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30-60%

Notes:

Make sure to use strong filament, even printed solid PLA is a bit weak for this.

Wanted something that raised my mini away from the floor, completely hid the cord, and elegantly held the speaker. After finding Jakewk13's design and seeing an image of something like what I wanted, credit to DannyG72 for the concept, I came up with this!
